We are moving to the manufacturing phase. Raw materials and logistics are taking 3-4x as long as usual because of breaks in the supply chain. We aren’t going to cut any corners in regards to our quality, as we want to make sure the end product lives up to its name. The process takes time, but we will get them to you as soon as humanly possible.

Status of the project: 

We have a working prototype for both the earplugs and the app. 

We have worked for months with our manufacturer to produce the injection mold needed to create the silicone part of the earplugs, and it's basically ready for mass production. We are now waiting for different filter samples to test in real live music environment and decide which one is best, and submit for testing and certification. We are working with one of the best testing laboratories in Germany, and they just need us to send them the final samples.

The carrying case doesn't need custom mold, and the manufacturing process is very simple once we make the order. 

The carrying case tray and packaging box for the earplugs has been already produced in mass when we did our proof of concept. We have a few improvements in our new design but we expect our printer to be able to execute without problems as they did last time.

For distributors, we still need to design the distributor pack, but it's a standard box that our printer produced in the past for other clients.

The app functions properly in both iOS and Android, but since we won't be able to test every model in the market, and every phone might receive slightly different sound signal depending on factors that we can't control, like how old or damaged is your microphone, we need to add a calibration section, so the users can adjust if needed. This is a quite simple implementation though. We have developed apps in the past and we are already approved as developers in both the Apple App Store and in Google Play.

For delivery, we are currently working with an award winning warehouse in the UK that will ship internationally in a professional and timely manner. 

Risks:

We are aware that the timeline for delivery in December is quite optimistic, but it's possible. We will do our best to deliver before Christmas because EarDial is the perfect present to any music-loving friend. Only if everything goes as expected we will be able to meet this deadline.

We think the risks and challenges are apparent in that we are trying to do something that we have never done before and maybe no one really has? There is so much that can go wrong! And that is exciting!
We have a remote control robot with live audio PA that will need both an operator and an actor.
We have a small rover droid that will need an operator.
We have hologram projections, pre recorded video projection, double sliding airlock doors, sliding hatches, computer screens, alien plant terrariums, captains chairs, LED floor lights, overhead panel lights, zero gravity suspension cable, rotisserie chicken food generator and probably a few other elements we have yet to discover!
We also have time.
We know we said we have a lot to accomplish in a short period of time and indeed it will fly by but 100% of our time from now until we open on Thursday, June 16th will be committed to this project. We are giving ourselves a full month of rehearsal and 8 days of full tech rehearsals to experience any problems that might arise in live performance.
How we plan to overcome anything that might risk the success of the project, is to be willing and ready to improvise and pivot creatively and technically.

The main risk for the project, should we hit our funding goal, will be ensuring tickets sales for the performances in August. We currently believe we have a strong plan for publicity and generating sales (Chris and Steve have both worked on a number of very successful Fringe shows previously) and we have been offered support by a number of local and national charities to help with that publicity.

The other possible risk is, of course, Covid-19. However, should that be the case then we will attempt to put together a virtual production so as to honour our commitments to our backers as well as our commitment to tell this important story.

For anyone investing in more than one issue at a reduced rate, we would want to make clear that we can only honestly deliver the full set, over the decade, if we sell enough of issues one, then two, three etc., to get us to the next issue, creating a domino effect to the conclusion of the final issue, number 10. If we create something that is compelling and significantly different to anything else out there, which is exciting and fresh (which is our aim!) this won’t, we feel, be a problem. But it’s a risk. 

With the pandemic we are aware this horrible virus might linger or return in a different manifestation. If it did, it would of course be tragic. For INQUE, like everyone else, there could be delays. There is not a strict print deadline for each issue, as long as it’s in its designated year (2021, 2022 etc.), so this isn't a major problem, but could consequently pose a challenge if we ran out of time in any given year. We are however working with printers who have the ability to stay open whilst maintaining safe social distancing.

Further, a challenge is figuring out how we package a valuable art print in each issue by our guest artist, without it falling out or into the wrong hands (i.e. someone who has not bought the magazine). We don’t want to have each issue shrink-wrapped, so need to resolve this. Also, deciding against having a digital edition, we need to work out how to ensure people know about the magazine online and have the access to pre-order issues. This balance between digital and traditional print marketing is a real challenge which we need to fully manage.

Um, yeah.  This was a gamble because we've already gone to print!  We had to in order to deliver the anthologies to our writers, artists, and community members at the once-a-year JAxByJax Literary and Arts Festival!  We didn't want to start our Kickstarter either until we KNEW we could make the deadline. So, here we are.  We need $4000+ to pay the printer, $2,500 to pay the professionals on our team and another $2,500 to pay for our website and other infrastructure. Nail-biting is ongoing!

Because this is a work-in-progress, it can be hard to understand how or why we are adamant about paying our artists.  Why can't we work for free if we are not actually producing a full-length show? As theater artists ourselves, we understand what it feels like to constantly be asked to work for free, or for less than we are worth. We are part of an industry that has a vested interest in paying creatives little to nothing, an exploitative practice that has gone on for far too long, making theater, both the creation and practice, accessible only to those with the right resources, funds, and connections.  This financial gatekeeping keeps artists from historically marginalized backgrounds out of the theater, and without a diverse theater community, whats the point of making theater at all? We, as artists, want to take part in widening access wherever possible.

But if that does happen, the show must go on, and we would work to find a replacement to join TWiD to keep educating the public and growing our community.

Because the pedals in this project are derived from previously established products, the biggest design challenges have already been addressed, and key parts are already on order. So the only real challenge is to meet the promised deadlines for shipping backer rewards.

Here is are some possible scenarios that could delay the shipment of your reward:
#1 - Parts do not arrive on time. In particular, the Vimex pots are not scheduled to arrive until early January. If this order is delayed, which is possible due to the high demand on the manufacturer leading up to the Chinese New Year, production will be delayed accordingly. If this happens, backers will have a choice on whether to receive their rewards on time with Alpha pots or wait for the glass-reinforced Vimex pots.
#2 - Orders of my other products exceed my production capacity, which may slow down overall production. My production schedule priority will go to filling backer rewards, so even if this does happen, it should not cause a lengthy delay.
#3 - January is the first month that my wife returns to work after a few months of maternity leave. The adjustment to a new daily rhythm and schedule may reduce my time in the shop, slowing down production.

The biggest challenge this time around is that we're actually aiming for an amount that would cover the expenses of putting out two issues next year. On one hand, given some of the past kickstarters there have been for fiction anthologies and new zines from people much more hip and cool than us, $5k is peanuts. On the other hand, it would require a significant increase in our existing readership to pull it off.

The increased number of backers would mean more copies having to be shipped out, which could either mean more time spent manually entering fulfillment information into Amazon and Lulu or time spent stuffing envelopes. Either way, there's a chance I'll be spending more time than in the past getting orders out to people.

The quarterly schedule has been pretty break-neck for us this year. However, I've made certain to get well ahead of the game on issues 9 & 10 so that nothing comes down to the wire. Even if we do get $10k, chances are we'll still go back to semi-annual for 2019. Excess funds will be used to get other projects off the ground as we look into doing more special releases like Wild Stars III.

As Editors, we have found an excellent working partnership that sticks to deadlines, and that above all has a great time producing it together. This foundation will ensure the launch of No.1 as well as the energy and excitement to move straight onto No.2. 

As an independent publication, our biggest challenge will be in its distribution. For the No.1 we are approaching stockists individually, but with lots of advanced planning and many existing contacts we are well on the way to ensuring it is widely stocked across the U.K. as well as in select stores in Europe and the U.S.A. Your advance sales will go a long way to helping us.

With our very trusted designers, Kris and Tom, we have a great working relationship with our printers to ensure excellent quality and expedient delivery.

Keep track of our progress via www.tintedwindowmag.com and Instagram (@tinted__window).

Can We Deliver?

We've been designing and manufacturing high-end audio equipment for more than 35 years. We know what it takes to make a vision come to life, and we will do our best to deliver your AxiomAir on time and to spec.

Although we've spent over 3 years in development, there are always unforeseen difficulties that may arise. There could be unexpected issues with the software that would result in updates happening after the product has shipped. (Requiring you to update the speaker from the interface.) There could be delays with component supplies or delivery that delay the project overall.  We pledge to keep you apprised of any unforeseen issues through regular updates.

We know great quality is hard to find, and with this project we cannot afford having bad quality components. That’s why we will manufacture it in UK to ensure only the best materials are being used. Any hardware project is a challenge so producing and shipping OnBlink out into the world won't be easy. We've spent considerable time assessing the potential risks, such as delays in component sourcing, issues with the process compatibility testing or fulfilment. Through understanding these processes we have strategies in place to keep the the project on time. Therefore we're confident that when we will face the challenges that inevitably come our way, we will be prepared to tackle them head on.

The reason we are shipping units in a small initial batch and a second larger one is so that we can ensure the highest quality for our backers. Assembling and shipping the first batch means we can ensure all the parts meet our spec and so we can make changes to manufacturing processes. We are confident that this is the best way to get the products to you as soon as possible.

Since QA is such a major focus for us, we’ll be testing components and subassemblies multiple times during the assembly process. Although this adds a little bit of time, it also ensures a robust product that can withstand you putting it through its paces for many years.

As with any manufacture there are inherit risks. We have planned meticulously and have secured a supply chain as well as a trusted manufacturer. However there is the possibility that there may be issues with tooling or other unforeseen issues that may delay delivery.
Our project does not require any approval or premarket review for it to be released.

Every movie project carries with it a great assortment of risks. With so many variables in the post-production and distribution processes, the only certainty in filmmaking is that things will go wrong. Solving problems, then, is an essential part of the process.

The producers of All Sorts have over 30 years of collective experience in filmmaking and have encountered, and overcome, many difficulties. Now that principal photography is complete, our largest risks are already behind us.

Our biggest challenge now is getting the movie completed and seen by as many people as possible. This can be overcome by clever and persistent promotion, generating buzz via social media, building a fan base, and getting the movie out on the festival circuit. We have already enjoyed a lot of early press and social recognition during filming in WA state, and have fed the momentum by sharing clips, stills and behind the scenes interviews on our website and social media platforms. This Kickstarter campaign will help us move All Sorts onward and upward!

Thanks again for your time and for supporting Independent Filmmaking!

The biggest risk for any comedy is for people to actually find it funny. We all know that terrible feeling you get when you try to make a joke and no one laughs. That is why we've taken time over the last few years to make a vast number of comedy sketches. These projects taught us the many pitfalls and challenges that come with comedy. 

We've learned that the writing, an actor's performance, and comedic timing are all major influences on whether or not a joke is well received. That's why we've spent over a year working on our script, going through multiple re-writes and beta readers to ensure our script is full of both humor and depth. We fully believe that each actor that has joined our team will be able to deliver an outstanding performance for their character, and we will work hard, both on location and in the editing room, to best showcase their performances visually and through comedic timing.

Another challenge we face is going to be standing out amidst all of the other video content that can be found out there today. We know that we can settle for nothing less than complete excellence in every aspect of the show. A few things we feel we have in our favor is a very unique concept, a good script, and an outstanding cast.

There have been many challenges in the past when it came to designing pedals and getting from idea to a physical working model. From finding the right parts to the hundreds hours of R and D, But there is always a way to overcome these challenges. Sometimes it was spending hours online looking for that one rare part or spending days and nights swapping parts and analyzing signals to get the desired outcome from the effect box. My biggest challenge has been raising money on my own to make a large order to suppliers to get the parts I need at a cost that wont kill the project before it can take off. I have overcome this by doing it in small steps, one week, purchase one part the next week get a few parts and eventually it all my designs came to life. Now that I have a few functional models it would be great to make a production run a get these great pedals out to musicians. This is why I am here at kickstarter. As for the "if" we are funded factor. I believe that most changes i will face from the "funded" point will plainly be time. I do work a full time job working audio for an event company. But so far this had not really slowed the process. When i am not working for the man, I am working on Vintage Efx. I put a lot of time into this project because i believe my years of experience in the field of audio has provided me with the skill set needed to deliver a unique and long lasting product. We honestly feel that our biggest challenges have already been overcome, its simply time to make these products, we just need a little financial push to really get of the ground and get our product to hundreds of players out there.

The major challenge facing any independent film is distribution. How do you get your movie out there for people to see? With the proliferation of streaming services and video-on-demand options, the opportunities are endless, but the goal for most filmmakers is still to get their film into theaters. 

The most obvious way to do that is by submitting the film to film festivals and hoping someone picks it up for distribution. Many film festivals receive thousands and thousands of submissions, but can only screen a hundred or so (if that), which makes this route of seeking distribution very difficult. In order to better your chances of succeeding on the film festival circuit, filmmakers need to develop a film festival plan.

As part of our plan we have factored film festival submission fees into our budget. 20% of our festival submission budget will go towards major festivals (Sundance, Cannes, Toronto, etc.), 50% will go towards mid-range festivals (South by Southwest, Slamdance, etc.), and 30% will go towards smaller/local festivals (Oak Cliff Film Festival, Dallas VideoFest, Dallas International Film Festival, etc.).

We have also created a festival submission timeline where we have researched each festival in-depth (their eligibility criteria, programming from previous years, etc.) and prioritized the festivals that a) our film has a better chance of getting into, and b) actually screen films versus those festivals that merely accept your submission money but don't do anything to promote it or get it in front of people.

About me:

My name is Lady Pixel Heart. I'm a professional freelance artist with 6+ years of experience making art. I draw mostly monthly commissions for people of their ocs, fanart, and sometimes my own characters.

Why Kickstarter??

In order to create these chapters I will need at least 2 months off from commissions. The money I usually make for taking 5-10 commissions each month helps pay for bills, groceries, and living expenses. 

If I can't get this time off of commissions I won't have time to work on the comic once it comes out on the 31st of October when I release the first 3 pages of Chapter 1. 

If I can raise the funds I will be able to produce the chapters right away giving my audience less time to have to wait for the next pages! But listen up, baby, we're film school undergraduates, which means we have a butt-load of anxiety (because we still have a lot to learn), but also if we're crazy enough to pay thousands of dollars so that we can be stressed out 24/7, then we're certainly crazy and passionate enough to finish this film and make it look better than we could have imagined. We want it to exceed the expectations of what a student film is assumed to be. Even if it kills us. Or at least Brianna. Hi, this is Brianna speaking and this film could literally kill me and I'll allow it because that's how much it means to me. Michael Cera also means a lot to me. Hi, Michael Cera. Our biggest challenges are going to be getting the kind of quality material we want in our magazine, and getting it to the people who want it most.

Getting material - A lot of publishers don't publish queer lit because they think it doesn't sell. Because of this, there aren't as many writers writing queer lit. By offering a competitive rate of pay for those who submit to our magazine, we can prove that it is worthwhile to write queer content, and encourage writers to submit to us. By running this kickstarter and gaining publicity and funding, we are proving there is a need, and there are people out there willing to pay for stories that represent who they are. All of this goes toward getting the writers and artists to create the work we want, and to give them an outlet to share those stories with the world. 

Getting it to the readers - This magazine is powered by a handful of young people with a passion for great fiction and great writing. We don't have a publishing company backing us up or a long list of connections in the writing world. What we do have is a strong social media presence, especially across tumblr, where we have all been active for years. Using our connections in the online queer and reading communities, we hope to spread this zine to everyone who ever said they wanted to read these kinds of stories.

The best way that I can prove to you that we're qualified to do this is to show you what we've already done. Please download our free minizine at readvitality.com!

Our goal is to ultimately celebrate the print medium and our previously published authors. We hope to get copies into the hands of many readers.

Printing costs & distribution are our biggest challenge, but I've already created PDFs of previous issues to make the anthology easier and it's a matter of minor copy-editing, design, and sending these out to the printer.

Our editors also have worked for various literary magazines in the past and understand the challenges that come with publishing, but we've consistently put out online editions of our work on a quarterly basis for the past three years now and welcome the challenge of doing print.

In an attempt to show that we are a solid group of artists with great working relationships, we created this Kickstarter Project having created something very similar on a smaller scale. Something to show that we have already come across, addressed and overcome such obstacles.

We're able to get work done without the weight of money issues. We simply need funding for the vast number of things needed to put together a project of this magnitude. While it is exciting to bring new plays to life on stage, it is always a big risk to small theatre companies. This is especially true when the play isn’t something easily recognizable to mainstream audiences or an adaptation of a well-known intellectual property. However, our playwright Maggie and director Amy are long-time collaborators who have gained a dedicated theatrical fan base in Seattle over the last 5 years. In addition, Macha Theatre Works has a proven track record of producing successful new plays, and has gathered a passionate, talented group of actors, designers, and staff for this project. We are committed not only to making the best art that we can, but also making it the best experience possible for everyone involved, from the start of rehearsal to the last curtain call. Theatre is only as strong as the team behind it, both on and off stage; we know we are strong and can overcome any risk that might arise along the way.

To mount this production at Park Theatre is a huge venture, and pushes my company to its limits. The overall budget required just to cover essential costs, such as venue costs, marketing, and fees for the actors and creatives involved, is £50,000 ($65,500). Ticket sales have been calculated to cover 40% of our expenses. We already have raised 30% of this sum from sponsors and supporters, and will cover 10% out of our own savings. 

To cover the remaining sum, we need more people to get behind this project! The money raised through this campaign will be used for set, costumes and props, to ensure a high-quality production.

There are many risks and challenges involved in completing a successful campaign. While this is our first crowdfunding campaign, we feel we have done an adequate job accounting for most factors. 

Shipping is our largest concern for two reasons, tight deadlines and international shipping. 

Ideally will ship the first round of pledges in time for Christmas, according to the USPS shipping deadlines (domestic shipping). This is a tight schedule, but assuming minimal delays, we are confident we can meet this deadline.

International shipping is something we were hesitant to offer. However we realize that a significant number of potential backers would be alienated by not offering an international option. As such we have done our best to  anticipate the associated costs. However while we do our best to anticipate problems, international backers will be responsible for applicable duties or tax, as well as ensuring items are not prohibited by customs in their country.

MARKETING: We are a small group of theatre artists in a very busy city. We hope to dedicate a portion of our fundraising to ensuring we have a strong enough marketing push to bring an audience out to see this important play. This includes investing in physical posters, targeted audience outreach, and online marketing content. This makes up $400 of the budget.

STIPENDS: While not every independent project in the city can afford to pay their actors and designers, we at Littlebrain Theatre are committed to compensating our artists for the work they do. More than $2000 of our $5000 budget goes exclusively to stipends for the artists. If we manage to fundraise beyond our budget, all overflow will go towards increasing actor and designer wages.

SIMPLE TECH: We do not currently have the resources to build massive sets or sew intricate period costumes for this play. We will be working with the resources we have to make the best possible adaptation of "Bicycle Thieves" we can. Your donations and support go towards helping us to hire the best designers for his project, who can work within the parameters of our simple production to create something impactful. Not to mention, each designer will receive a budget to make sure they can afford to create what they need to for the production.

We have a proven track record of producing high quality, accessible theatre, with extensive experience marketing these productions to a diverse audience and managing large scale budgets.

What's most important to us is raising the funds to pay our incredible team of actors and creatives, and the only risk is that we might fall short.

We have the team, we have the theatre, we have the play. Now we just need you.

The biggest risk we're taking on this project is shooting in a method we've never done before. Although we are excited to showcase this more theatrical style through the camera lens, we are aware that things may take longer that expected and that not every line from our script might make it into the final product. In preparation for that, we will be consulting with a few Shakespeare and theater experts before the shooting date, even setting up rehearsals as if we were really putting on a play. 

Another challenge is shooting on location rather than one of our own homes where we might have more control. This means that we have to be extremely wary of what we touch, where we put things, and making sure the area looks exactly as it did when we first got there. Think of it as being a guest in someone else's home, but having a group of 10-15 other people with you!

Wir setzen alles daran, dass wir den M2 termingerecht ausliefern können. Unsere Lieferanten sind bereit und sollten alle Komponenten rechtzeitig liefern können. Wir leben für unseren Traum. Damit dieser Traum Realität wird, haben wir bewusst darauf verzichtet, externe Investoren für Euphony zu gewinnen. Wir möchten unabhängig bleiben und frei über Geschäftsstrategien, Gewinnmargen etc. entscheiden. Um finanziell über die Runden zu kommen, müssen wir neben Euphony einen "normalen" Job ausüben. We do everything we can to deliver the M2 in time. Our suppliers are ready and should be able to deliver all components as soon as ordered. The biggest challenge will be the transfer of production to the appropriate social institution. We would like to have prepared this part better, but we lacked the financial resources. For this reason, we will probably not be able to produce the first speaker completely externally.
We live for our dream. To make this dream a reality, we have deliberately refrained from winning external investors for Euphony. We want to remain independent and decide freely on business strategies, profit margins, etc. In order to make ends meet financially, we have to work in a "normal" job as well. For this reason, we will not be able to offer a professional support service right from start. This means that we will not always be reachable over the phone right away, and won't be able to answer every mail on the exact same day.

In an effort to minimize risks, we have spoken with all suppliers to learn the stock of components, manufacturing times and times of shipments etc.
Even so, we are not completely safe from possible inconveniences but in the case of this happening we will report to our sponsors and we will not stop until we solve it.

We plan to increase our shipping and customer service capacity by hiring out help for these two potential bottlenecks. But we plan to address each of these by a case by case scenario. Finally, there are quality control issues that may arise. We plan to personally do a quality control check of the shipment before it leaves China. We are confident that we can overcome any challenges that come our way.

A successful Kickstarter campaign will allow us to take advantage of bulk printing discounts and provide an easy to read and use tool that will help  people transition to a gluten-free diet in a healthy, economical, and tasty way. 

Our first cookbook "Transitioning to a Gluten-Free Lifestyle with Healthy & Easy Recipes" provides information on how to get the process started including tips on identifying gluten, kitchen set up, and shopping. 

"Summer Recipes" provides a wide variety of recipes to take advantage of summer fun and provides tips and techniques for avoiding cross-contamination during summertime events. 

We were astounded at how expensive wedding and special event gluten-free cakes are (and how much sugar is used!) and knew we could do better. "Wedding Cakes" will show you how to create fabulously beautiful and tasty cakes with lower sugar cake frosting, and cakes at a fraction of the normal costs. We show you pictures of the cakes we created and take you step by step through the process including tips for decorating, staging, and serving!

"Let's Party" will help you host parties or bring food to parties that is gluten-free, nutritious, and inexpensive. Again we are focusing on how to minimize cross contamination as well as how to create a feast in style with totally yummy foods! We created a table full of scrumptious food for around $40!

Our newest book "Transitioning Kids to a Gluten-Free Lifestyle with Healthy & Nutritious Foods" provides a wealth of recipes that will delight both kids and adults will like, that are fun to eat, and easy to prepare! There are projects that are easy enough to involve your younger kids with and healthy foods (cleverly disguised as a lot of fun) that will help kids make the transition to a healthier lifestyle. 

The sample cookbooks have already been created and only minor changes are needed (like adding ISBN numbers) to make them print ready. If we are not successful, we will work harder to improve our campaign and continue to produce new titles to help both kids and adults through the process. We are on a mission to help our families, our friends, and others who have been dramatically, and tragically, impacted by gluten make this critical transition. We need your help to help others.

Our product is still at the prototype stage, thus, to transition from prototype to finished product will pose as a challenge to our team. While the functionalities work well as a prototype, we want to continue improving our product to be more sturdy and function well as a finished product to deliver the greatest value to our backers. We have done several tests on our products to ensure that they work well consistently, and continue to execute more tests to improve the product. We are also continuing work on the prototype to develop newer and better versions of PAU.

Manufacturing is one of the largest challenges for our product. Every product faces significant difficulties when transitioning from the prototype to the product stage, and ours is no different. In order to mitigate the risk of this transition, our team carefully screened potential partners.
In October, we went to Shenzhen to visit hardware manufacturers. We were able to find a manufacturer who was able to manufacture and assemble both the shell and the PCB together, and had successfully manufactured for Kickstarter products before, so will be able to help us fulfill our goals.

Risks and challenges This project is designed, managed and fully executed by MERKUR, a watch group founded in 2016. We are not dependant of third parties, this watch collection follows same product life cycle as any other new models from other brands within our group. We plan to start our delivery process in Jun 2021. While we are fully confident in our campaign goals, there may be some unexpected issues in our production and shipping process beyond our control. If unexpected things happen, the MERKUR team promises to keep all our backers updated and informed and handle the concerns with care. We will work closely with the logistics company in advance to make sure the process goes smoothly. Please be aware that there may be extra customs fees due to the policy of different countries. Backers will be responsible for customs fees, duties, VAT, import taxes, etc. administered by your government. They are excluded from the shipping fees. Normally, you won't be charged import duty taxes. However, given many different regulations in different countries, We can't guarantee that 100%. Every PIERRE PAULIN watch will be posted to each backer on the same day. However, shipping time will vary from country to country. Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

CHALLENGES.

The issue #1: PLANNING
When you talk to us about the play, you will hear excitement, joy, wonder, and... that it's tiring. We are working on this because it's a labour of love. We love it and many of us work on the play in our spare time and in between hours to fundraise, promote, write, create, plan and produce.
 
The solution: 
We endeavour to work to a clear production schedule which maps out not only what needs to be done, but also how to mitigate risks, move times lines and help juggle the opposing time schedules of Philip and Avni! 


The issue #2: A LARGE CAST
We envisage challenges on the way; preparing the actors, managing schedules, rehearsal spaces, cast expectations, as well as using the opportunity to support them to develop professionally. Importantly, we want to pay them fairly.
 
The solution: 
We love our actors and they bring a wealth of experience and knowledge to their roles. They are well versed in Eastern European literature, or have personal connections to the themes. From this foundation of respect, we will endeavour to work with them to manage expectations, provide concrete and manageable schedules to work with, respond to feedback and offer them support. This kickstarter is a perfect opportunity to start this journey.


The issue #3: We’re doing this for the FIRST TIME!
Philip and Avni are working towards their debuts in directing and producing, respectively, as well as bringing the play to the UK stage for the first time!
 
The solution: 
Both Philip and Avni have trusted mentors who are experts in the field. They are working closely with them to identify potential issues, work through problems and offer guidance along the way. They have also spent over a year researching the play, it’s ideas and the writer – speaking with academics, technicians, producers, psychologists and engaging the polish community. It is through these meticulously built and strong foundations that the play has a platform from which to succeed. 

 
THE RISKS
 
The issue #1: SMELL DESIGN
Using scents as part of the performance is ambitious, and we want to get it right. It runs the risk of being tokenistic.
 
The solution: 
We work closely with Harry and Sarah from 4160 Tuesdays perfume who are experts and have a lot of experience in this area. With Avni’s work at festivals and in performances using scent, there is a practical and creative vision which emerges. It will be tested in rehearsals to ensure it works and enhances the play. We will ensure Harry and Sarah are present to advise and inform throughout.
 
We would also like to test the innovation of using scent to get into character for the actors - a unique way of preparing actors for the performance.
 

 
The issue #2 : NOT REACHING THE GOAL
This goal is one generous step in a long journey.
 
The solution: 
We believe in equality, fairness and collaboration. If we reach the goal we can start the journey as we mean to go on, and do this performance justice, not only for it being a seminal piece of literature, but as a positive marker for women and help open conversations about equality in all of it’s forms. 

 
Any donations that meet (or even exceed) our goal, will be incredibly appreciated.
 
Thanks again everyone and happy fundraising!

Risk:
As with any new business adventure, there are risks.  Most risk can be calculated and procedures put into place to overcome those risk.  In the Vermicomposting community, the risk is always the same.  "Consistency".  Finding the right combination of soil composition and bedding to grow worms successfully then maintaining that standard.  Other factors are what the worms are fed and how often. Most or all of the large Commercial Vermicomposters feed straight "Composted Cow Manure".  We don't!  Moisture content, temperature and PH are other important factors.  Throughout the last year, we have perfected a system that have our worms maturing sexually in 8-10 weeks instead of the normal 10-12 week time frame.  Once mature they start to produce 2-3 eggs a week and each egg casing on average is producing 2-3 healthy juveniles.  The fact that we started with 1000 worms and even lost half of that batch due to inexperience in the first 3 months then came back strong is testament to our commitment to being the best in the field.  We don't give up.

Unexpected Obstacles:
We’ve worked out all the kinks that one usually encounters while farming worms.  Not sure of what could or would be unexpected seeing as we’ve encountered most if not all the obstacles one expects in this industry. 

No pending projects.

Most of what we encountered in the beginning was typical of what others in the industry have gone through.  We were able to confer with other successful wormers.  However, experience is still the best teacher.  This last year has been a learning experience.  Additionally, we were not afraid to try new things based on what we were learning about what makes a good earth worm.  We have had great success and will be keeping many of these new techniques proprietary.

I have calculated that I can paint thirty 22" x 60" scarf panels per 5 day work-week. A five day schedule leaves two days for catch up and problem solving. This allows Two weeks for painting. At the end of week one the first thirty scarves can go to my seamstress for hemming. Second week, the next thirty, so as I'm painting, she is hemming. I have contracted with her before on another project and was happy with her work and delivery. Should she show any delivery problems, I have a recommended alternative for back-up. 
   My supplier of silk has a large and diverse inventory, in a broad spectrum of colors. The inks I use are well stocked at my local art supply store. I also have alternate sources in Los Angeles.
    I have already painted prototypes of the scarves as Christmas gifts for friends and family. They were very well received. I know my painting technique and production process, which is how I calculated my production capacity.
    I think the Artisan Festival is a good venue to launch the line and assess the public response. Any remaining inventory from sales at the Artisan Festival can be offered on an Etsy store and through local specialty boutique shops and art galleries. Market research shows hand painted silk scarves sell  between $45 upward to $80+ each. I intend to offer at a retail price of $80.
  My studio is in my home, and has sufficient space for the production of this initial venture.

This is a low risk project. The main challenge will be to make sure the individual works, which are heavier than the average panels and occasionally have fragile  additions, are crated and shipped with care.

I've found that the most difficult thing in becoming a financially successful artist is acquiring the right following.  A gallery can be useful for it's mailing list, but there have to be enough art collectors, designers, and other clients interested in my work to provide enough income to live and have a full-time studio practice.  In New York there are many gallery's that can provide this for but can charge the me anywhere from 40-75% on the sale price of the artwork.  In London it is common for an emerging artist to rent a space for an exhibition but will not necessarily receive promotional help from the gallery.  I have chosen to have my first solo exhibition in The Annexe of The Brick Lane Gallery.  The space is for rent, but also gives me access to their extensive mailing list.  Hopefully, with both of our promotional efforts, this exhibition will produce a crowd capable of propelling my career and producing opportunities I wouldn't otherwise have.  Luckily, I have many friends in the art world who can help me with this DIY approach and with your help, can use this well located space and their resources to put together a very professional, well-represented exhibition.

The biggest risk with any food related production, is ensuring that it is safe for consumers. All food products need to be produced in a commercial kitchen, licensed by the state, and inspected by the local health department. By having the funding to expand into a true commercial kitchen space, we ensure that our customers are receiving only the highest quality for their money. 

The biggest challenge is in finding your market for a specialized food item. Right now, our country is extremely unhealthy, and very unwilling to change - we like convenience! Our products offer a healthy alternative, without sacrificing quality or taste. The ability to advertise to a wider market, would give us the exposure we need to take our business to the next level.

We are all proud of the music we write and play and we have no doubt that whatever comes from this will be a debut we're all proud of. But there is a lot of uncharted territory too. Our band members, while united by a common love for the music we make, come from very different musical backgrounds, ranging through jazz, progressive rock, classical, indie rock, and pop. A lot of work will go into reconciling our individual musical instincts to create a unified whole sound that is distinctly ours.
Another challenge is that we're still a very young band, most members having only worked together for less than a few months. Because of this, we don't know exactly what our sonic profile should sound like, and, perhaps more importantly, how to create a record that we can accurately reproduce live. That's what we have our producer for, fortunately, and his experience and wisdom will serve us well in the coming months as we explore the tracking together.
This band has a great work ethic. We rehearse constantly, communicate well, and fight like mad to make sure each song is perfect. It's these qualities that will carry us through any difficulties we encounter in the recording process. We are so excited to share a well-crafted recording with you soon!

Keeping Shiny Spoons very local, at only three Whole Foods Market stores for the first six months, allowed us to spot and fix any issues found in our “trial” period.

It’s taken months to fine-tune the equipment and create a smooth, efficient workflow in our new production facility. 

We plan to avoid risks by growing wisely in stages, and eliminating any arising issues as we grow.

Please be aware that we may have a large list to get through so it could take up to 7 days to receive your product. If you do not receive your digital content by December 22nd, please forward your kickstarter pledge email to oddvoiceout@gmail.com and we will rectify the situation.

Combining cats and coffee has presented challenges at every step of this process. Our main remaining risks and challenges are below: 

Risk 1 - If our Zoning Variance as an animal boarding facility is not approved. We will have an answer for this March 28th, which is during our Kickstarter. We have been in contact with the city planning department for awhile and knew this would be a box to check. The city officials have been extremely helpful and while it's always possible, we are not overly concerned about this being denied. If for some reason we are denied, and can't fight it in any other means, we will cancel the Kickstarter and no one will be charged. 

Risk 2 - If the Kickstarter fails. This would be bad on several levels. The biggest problem is that it would be an indication for us that Dayton is too small to support a unique business like a cat cafe. We have invested heavily with our time and emotions, and we've certainly sunk some costs into this dream. If the failure is extreme, we may call the project off. If the failure is slight, we would consider turning the upstairs into a residential or commercial rental to scale down the size and operating expenses of the catfe and press on. 

Risk 3 - If we run of our money before we open. We've laid out planned expenses, built spreadsheet after spreadsheet, and built a business plan. However, we still lose some sleep over this one because of the unknowns with a project of this type. Our building purchase and renovation costs are covered through one loan and we hope to raise the funds for the cafe equipment from this Kickstarter campaign. It would be amazing if we hit our stretch goals and were able to cover the furnishings as well with Kickstarter funds. Otherwise, the furnishings and first few months of expenses will be paid out of our savings but if we needed to take a small business loan on these items, we would be able to do so. 

Risk 4 - If large changes are requested with our building permit or from the health department. It would be uncomfortable, costly, and push our project back, but we would be able to keep moving and work within the requirements.

RISK AND CHALLENGES, BUT WE HAVE SOLUTIONS 

As with any exciting new venture there will be risks and challenges to overcome, the essential thing is to have a plan and to put it in action. Confident AFF will be an important platform for many filmmakers and audiences, we are committing hard work to it because we want to get it right!
Below is a list of the risks and challenges we have identified and how we are going to overcome them:

Risk/challenge:
Protecting intellectual property.

Solution:
We want as many people to see the films but we also must ensure they are protected from piracy. We will do this by making sure the website we create is a secure platform to showcase the work. To view the films the audience will need to sign up and log in and will not be able to download the films. We will be spending a great part of our budget building a safe film community. 

Risk/challenge:
To ensure every submission is fairly judged.

Solution:
It is essential that every submission is given equal attention. The Accents team will watch and review every film. The reviewers have all studied film or work in the industry and press so they bring a strong understanding of film. Once the initial selection is made the films will go to a judging panel. We aim to have a panel of judges who are all industry professionals of note who will be able to bring different areas of expertise.

Risk/ challenge:
With over 3000 film festivals active in the world one could consider the market over saturated. We may face a challenge of creating interest in another film festival in an already saturated market.

Solution:
We see Accents as a cutting edge, new platform for a film festival. We are looking for a particular type of filmmaker who does not have a dedicated film festival yet. Furthermore the online platform endures accessibility for the filmmakers and audience so we believe we will be able to reach a large crowd. Using part of our budget for promotion on sites such as Withoutabox, Filmfreeway we will be able to reach out to a large number of already active filmmakers.

We hope you want to share our vision and thank you for the vote of confidence. If you think we have missed anything out or wish to give us some information, please write to us!
info@accentsfilmfestival.com

The artwork for the pins is complete and I have gotten pricing from my pin manufacturer, so there are only two areas where there are possible risks/challenges during this process:

Production: there can always be errors in manufacturing with any pin. My manufacturer offers a guarantee that should there be more than 10% "seconds" in the pins I receive, they will remake the pins with issues at no additional charge. I have had excellent success with them in the past several runs of producing pins. Should there be a manufacturing issue that results in pins having to be remade, it will delay backers receiving their pins -- but I think it is better to receive a beautiful pin even if there is a few weeks' delay.

Shipping: as I am shipping from Canada, it is likely that most backers will be in the USA or overseas, which means that packages will have to cross an international border and could be delayed by customs. It also means that tracking may be too cost-prohibitive to offer, so I will not be able to update process of packages as with a tracked package. I will have to ask for backers' patience in receiving their pins as it will not be as speedy as they are used to receiving packages sent from within their own country. And should there be any issues in receiving the pins not accounted for by postal slowness, I will be happy to work with backers to make sure missing or damaged pins are replaced.

If you have any other questions or concerns, I'll be happy to try and answer them to the best of my ability. Thank you!

Opening a restaurant is never easy, and we are aware that many restaurants fail within a short time after opening.
Both of us have experience in restaurants of varying levels, and also in other industries, all of which will complement this venture.  We have a great team of experts behind us who are helping make our vision a reality.

Bringing dogs to bars and restaurants is technically illegal in NYC - however, as of March 2015, it is at the restaurant owner's discretion to decide whether dogs are allowed in outside areas or not (http://legislation.nysenate.gov/pdf/bills/2015/S4327A)

Officially though, dogs cannot be in the areas where food is served or prepared. We have found loopholes to get around this regulation, though.

Since we are planning our first location in Brooklyn, we are aware of the potentially cold winters here - therefore, we will make our outdoor area as pleasant as possible - serving hot drinks (think mulled wine and hot cider), providing blankets and a source of heat (heat lamps, covered fire pits etc).
However, we will, of course, have an indoor area as well.
Essentially, our (human) guests will go to our food/drink establishment, order whatever they'd like and then take it to the seating area next door/outside. We will basically be running two businesses under the same roof.

Human and dog safety are our top priority and we'll have a Bark Ranger on site who will interfere if trouble arises, ultimately, dog owners are responsible for their dog's actions.

As with my previous kick-starter campaign, I don't like to take big risks. I ask for help at the last minute, well after I've done everything I can. (Although one day, I hope to try new methods!) Therefore there are practically no risks for backers.

The film has already been written, shot, edited and scored. We are in the absolute final stages of audio mixing, which will probably be done by the time this kick-starter is launched. I will then test it with Chris on the projector, make any adjustments, test again (I usually aim for first or second test to be the final one), then it's done. If I die, the show goes on. If the cinema gets fried by a dragon, then we might have a problem.

Since the campaign ends the day before the premiere, the film is scheduled to be tested within a week from now. The only risks are technical ones, computers deciding to fight me, which I am pretty used to by now! If some horrific freak technical problem happens and the Premiere can't go on, then I would know well before the kick-starter would end, and would not allow it to take the money from its backers in the first place. 1. Manufacturing problems
 Manufacturing can require a lot of expensive trial and error, with
cost of materials and availability of essential tools changing regularly. This is why we've built in a margin for error into our Kickstarter goal.

2. Design flaws 
While we have gone to every effort to predict how device foo will work in the real world, the reality is, we're Kickstarting this because it's never been seen before. That means that unpredictable problems with the design will likely come up. There is a risk, that one of these
could be problematic, however, by using the most advanced computer aided design techniques, we've minimized this risk to the level that anyone can. We've worked through many issues before and don't plan on stopping if we hit a roadbump. We will always keep you updated of new developments.

3. Illness / injury / death 
Unlikely, but this is a small team, and it's always possible that
something could happen to one of us. That said, we have a team precisely so create strength beyond what any one of us could create. In the event of something getting in the way of one us completing the project, we are all committed to pulling together, taking up the slack, and ensuring this project gets done. Period.

Is there some other potential issue you're wondering about?
If you're wondering, others probably are, too! We'd appreciate it if you'd email it to us at:

nainagade@gmail.com

 and I'll personally make sure it gets answered for you.

80% of the filming is already finished. Yippee! No risk there. The remaining footage, however, will be a challenge, but it's one I'm prepared to tackle. In particular, cuttlefish and squid will be difficult to film. They are finicky creatures, and I'll need excellent macro lenses to capture the ultra-fast movements of their chromatophores as they change color.

I'm confident, though, that with a photographer's patience, artist's eye, and engineer's technique, plus the help of the invertebrate experts at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, we'll be able to capture this tricky footage.

The first risk for #MakeArtHappen is that I won't reach my funding goal of £2000. I've thought carefully about this goal and have done lots of maths to work out that by reaching this goal I will be able to provide backers with a quality product at the end of this project, as well as have enough to finance my trip to BCTF. 

If I don't reach my funding goal, I will still be going to BCTF, but I will have to find financing elsewhere - I have several different funding ideas on the go right now, so my hope is that between all of them I will get to BCTF and have enough products to make some trade deals. 

If I exceed my funding goal, this will mean a bigger range of products will be on display at BCTF, increasing my chances of making an impression on traders. When I signed up for BCTF, I was told that often new exhibitors don't make much money until the second or even third time they attend, so further money now will continue to be invested in my business for the future.

I have an income from the four lodgers in my house in Cardiff, South Wales, which will enable the B&B to run successfully.

I work in the social housing sector, so I am well qualified to work with different types of people and deal with the financial side of the business. I also have a good accountant. I have to have an enhaunced CRB certificate checked yearly by the police authority to work in the social housing sector, this enables me to work with vulnerable people and children.

Risks:  1. Renovating old houses always uncovers things that need to be addressed. We have budgeted low in this area and we hope that works out for us. 2. There are already to go food places in town though none remotely similar to what we want to create and none specialize in offering local food (to our knowledge).

Challenges: 1. Changing behaviors. The winter traffic in Kingfield on Friday afternoons, Saturdays, and Sundays can be so thick, it takes a couple minutes to pull out into it safely. Drivers seem to have tunnel vision when it comes to getting through town. Grabbing their attention, getting them to stop, and get their regular business will be a challenge. 2. Getting locals out in the winter. When it gets dark at 4, getting people out and off the couch will be a challenge. We have some ideas to make this happen.

Doing this project as a foreigner in Vietnam is a challenge by itself. The huge cultural differences as well as the different approaches of getting things done, the standards of production and execution, are far from what we are used to in Europe. This is an exciting, but at times also very frustrating challenge. But having lived part-time in Vietnam for over 6 years now, and with the help of my partner, who has worked in Mui Ne for 9 years and speaks enough of the language to communicate with the builders and local authorities about all issues, we are confident to follow through with the project. As you have mentioned, every project comes with its own unique risk and challenge. In my case, being first in something that was not done before is one of the most crucial risks. This project has been in the air for more than 2 years and finally, I get to its core and can fully concentrate on it. There were a lot of delays, unplanned circumstances but now it is my main project on the table.

Trying something new always involves risks.  
Since we started our farm we have faced- and overcome- many obstacles.  Our first syrup season was the worst maple production year in recorded history, so we began developing ways to sell & market our products directly that increased awareness & opportunities for maple syrup.  We focused on innovation & experience instead of competing against friends & neighbors on price.  A catastrophic flood wiped out our roads and washed away our sap collection equipment- we built bridges, improved infrastructure, and rebuilt our trails in a sustainable manner to better weather the next storm.  COVID cancelled in-person events, our largest source of revenue; we spent almost a year developing Embark so we could bring the good energy of our forest directly to you.  Resilience is built into the very fabric of who we are as people and as a company.


Potential Risks & Challenges:
-Supply Chain Disruptions causing delays:
One of the biggest challenges we have faced are supply chain disruptions due to the pandemic, which may result in production delays.  All of our ingredients we have either produced directly on our farm or have built relationships with other producers to secure the quality & quantities needed for our launch.  There are some factors, such as packaging timelines, that are beyond our control.  If any delays do occur,  we will stay in constant contact with our backers, and will have your adventure packs to you as soon as they are available.  Above all, we will stand behind delivering a quality experience.

- Reward Fulfillment Delays:
Over the years we have developed efficient order fulfillment systems for our current line of maple syrup, and  we are well prepared to meet the shipping demands we anticipate with this project.  There is the potential that this project is successful beyond our wildest dreams and we need an extra few days to get everything shipped.  If this happens we will redirect our crew to making sure everything is shipped as soon as possible.

- Scheduling Conflicts & Weather Variables
We are extremely excited to share our beautiful forest with everyone who chooses an Embark Experience reward.  We will have a schedule of available times for you and your group to visit the farm, and will do everything we can to accommodate your scheduling preferences, but it is possible that you may not get your first choice weekend, or that the weather is not what you hope for.  In the event of weather cancellations we will do our best to reschedule a time that works for you.

I have been a composer my whole adult life, and throughout a career of composing, teaching, and running music schools, have established a voice which I think The New York Times described pretty well: “fashioned with the clean, angular melodies, tart harmonies, lively syncopations and punchy accents of American Neo-Classicism ... the textures are always lucid; details come through.” I bring to my composing of American Pilgrimage a tremendous passion for the diversity and emotional breadth of our country, as well as a musical language to express this passion honed by the almost 100 works I have composed in the course of my career. The challenge of bringing a new work to life is always a daunting one, but I am lifted up and inspired by the extraordinary artistry of the American String Quartet, who are true collaborators in this project.

As with any business start up - we have risks.  The biggest is the financial risk.  We want to fund most, if not all, of the business on our own through saving and making the best decisions we can.  We have growth risk - both fast or slow growth would impact our lives and we have to be prepared to adapt to both.  We are confident our cookies will sell and people will want them but the challenge will be to ensure consistent sales strategies as well as production.  Another big challenge for us will be to operate effectively and efficiently to meet demand:  focused prep time and baking time, allotted time for packing and shipping and most importantly time to learn and adapt as needed when we have great feedback from our supporters.

We've built this Company because we really believe that it fills an important need in the Fraser Valley food ecosystem.

We know that change takes time. Changing the shopping habits of local people will take time. We also know that time costs money. We've built the platform for small vendors and farms to sell their delicious goods direct to you at home.  Now we need to develop the products and curate the meal bundles to ensure we are able to meet the weekly food needs of families, and bring local food into the homes of everyone in the Fraser Valley every week.  

Your support will allow us to invest in buying more local foods throughout the harvest season, and hire more passionate people to create products with those locally harvested fresh foods. This is no easy feat considering we are in the midst of a period of unparalleled uncertainty due to the pandemic. 

Time will allow us to rebuild our customer's relationship with local food, and deliver a much-needed service that enables everyone in the Fraser Valley to get fresh food to their families table each week. This same service will put money back into the hands of our farmers, artisans, chefs as well as those most in need within our community.

We would love to see other organizations “competing” to serve these teens and young adults.  And, to be fair, there are organizations that mentor youth. There are also companies that have workbook-related content in some of the areas our resource material gives an overview on. Different organizations focus on school programs, juvenile aged youth, prison transition, the foster care industry and church youth programs. We believe that this solidifies the need of our material and creates our advantage because we can be an addition to all of them. We stay general in nature and can redirect our marketing based on technology trends where others cannot without considerable disruption. For example, if an area has a high drug overdose rate in teens, we will focus on that subject. If they experience a high dropout rate in the local schools, we center our marketing to parents. The content we offer exposes obstacles and society’s challenges with the resources they can turn to that focuses on that topic without causing harm to themselves. Our competition is limited in scope and resources for the vertical markets we seek to gain market share in. We will bridge the gap from specific content to a society balanced lifestyle.

I have put many years into the formulation of my ideas and understanding of humans, both ancient and modern. I have a good chunk of this material written in some basic form, but I know that writing quality content comes in chunks. One issue I currently have is my full time job. I could potentially run into an issue of not having enough time to finish the book and get it to backers by the proposed date. I understand this is a very plausible situation. However, I personally enjoy doing research and writing, so I do not think I will run into any significant setbacks due to a time constraint. If I am able to travel for on-location research, there is more of a possibility of that causing a time delay than anything else. If the opportunity to visit any archaeological site does arise, I will be extremely conscious of my time to ensure my efforts are calculated and targeted at the most pertinent information for my cause. I am extremely focused and driven to make this a great book that is accurate, informative, and enjoyable to read. If I run into an issue finding a publisher, I will use any remaining funding, and any funds I can personally provide, to self publish the book.

Writer's block:
Every so often a writer is faced with writer's block, where they have no new ideas. I have had writer's block and it is the worst. However, with Soul's Endurant, the story completely done, in my head. All I have to do now is put it on paper.
Finding the time:
Writing out a story on paper takes more time then you'd think. Then once you've written it, no matter how perfect it sounded in your head, you generally want to change it. Part of the funds from this project will allow me to drop one of my jobs so that I can focus that time on finishing this book by mid-August.

The first challenge that comes to mind will be the editing because after the first edit, I know that there will be time needed to review it and there will be re-writes and more editing. This can no doubt be frustrating and the least appealing part of the process (as it is for most writers), but my dedication to this will be more than enough to see it through. It’s a process and each step is important no matter how tedious. Luckily, I am VERY ambitious. 

Formatting issues may also arise as I strive to get things looking the way I want them as far as the pages and overall feel of the book turns out just before publication. There can be issues with printing errors and distribution, or even ISBN assignments after publication but all one can do is work with your team and take each challenge as they come. Work through one and move onto the next and that is exactly what I plan to do. 

Aside from the cost of publication and any technical issues, the biggest challenge I can foresee is that publishing my book will be take longer than I would like it to. I understand that publishing can be a long and sometimes stressful process which can test anyone’s patience; I’m sure it will mine. But being the stubborn, strong-willed, and hard working person that I am, I know that I will get through it no matter how many challenges come my way.
I don’t have the funds for something so big under such a large household name like Forbes and is why I’m asking for help.

I already have world-class musicians on board, as well as a Grammy winning engineer, so the team is already in place, as is the studio. 

The only real challenges to getting this project made once funded are scheduling difficulties. The plan is to rehearse extensively in August and record sometime in September. While everyone is committed to meeting this schedule, we are all working professionals in the film/TV industry. We may have to delay the recording to accommodate other projects that may come up.

The album is scheduled for release in December, leaving ample time for unforeseen delays while keeping the December release.

Budget overages are the other possible risk. If the recording sessions take longer than anticipated, it adds costs - more studio time, added musician and engineer costs. Having worked on countless recording sessions, I have a very good idea of how much music I can record in how many hours and have budgeted accordingly. We're also rehearsing extensively ahead of the sessions, which will help ensure we stick to our recording schedule.

Throughout the development of this project, we've struggled to convey the unique look, feel and humor that sets Lily & Kosmo apart.

Without a frame of reference based in today's movies or TV, people often attempt to relate it to other children's entertainment.  "Is it animated?  It should really be animated."  "I could really see this as a Pixar movie!"  Or, "Live action, huh?  But you're going to have some really awesome CGI, right?"

While there are some really movies and shows for kids today, we're trying to offer something different.  The handmade feel, performances by real, everyday kids, and a heroine who's not a princess, will make Lily & Kosmo a truly refreshing offering for today's kids (and we're pretty sure their parents will like it too).

We're confident that when people see what we're making, it'll all make sense!

This is our seventh Kickstarter campaign, and that in itself is a testament to our experience. We have delivered all the rewards from our first campaigns and we have learned a lot in the process.

Our book-publishing house is located in France, so we have a strong grasp of the production chain here. With new territories, come new risks, but we're more prepared than ever to face them.
- Localization: We have now produced 22 books in English. The process is already quite solid, but we are constantly working on ways to improve it.
- International distribution: We now have two fulfilment centers, one in Europe and one in North America. This reduces delivery delays as well as costs for many of our backers.
- International marketing: The marketing channels we use to publish our French books are not very useful to us when it comes to our books in English. We have found partners to distribute in bookstores, but we are still a relatively small player on the international scene and the task of creating visibility for our products lies upon our shoulders. This is clearly one of the reasons why we are returning to Kickstarter, as this has proved to be a powerful way for us to reach our readers.

I have been making enamel pins since 2017, so have a good understanding of the process. The only potential risks/challenges that could occur should be be shipping delays etc - but any issues that occur will be notificed through the updates.

Risks and challenges

Living in Portugal and making it a priority to produce all our sneakers and socks in Portugal enabled us to visit and get to know quite a lot of suppliers until we met a factory that had the same values as us and that helped us create this campaign.

It was a challenge to come up with something unique that reflected our vision but we are confident that the Sneakers and socks we created are exactly what we set out to create!

Of the founding team we have plenty of experience in logistics and in FMCG to carry out this project and we are confident we set conservative timelines.

The 2 main risks that we cannot control that can slightly affect delivery are the supply chain disruptions (which are minimized by the fact that all our suppliers are located within a few hours drive from the factory) and the consistent change in shipping prices lately.

We commit to over-communicating with our backers to make sure that you know all progress during our production and shipping.

Nous avons  besoin de votre aide pour que l'entreprise prendre pleinement vie!

Les prototypes et les unités de pré-production ont tous été financés personnellement.

Aujourd'hui, pour se lancer en grand, nous devons faire face à des dépenses initiales élevées, surtout si l'on souhaite poursuivre notre production au Québec.  Nous devons également couvrir de gros coûts de production et de commercialisation.

La plateforme Kickstarter nous permet de gérer une pré-vente de manière concrète et efficace sans engager de coûts supplémentaires.

We need your help to bring the business to life!

Prototypes and pre-production units were personally funded.

Today, to get off to a great start, we have to face high initial expenses, especially if we want to do our production in Quebec. We also have to cover large production costs: equipment, raw materials and installations.

Kickstarter allows us to manage a pre-sale in a concrete and efficient way without incurring any additional costs for the adjustment of our website.

- Manufacturing delays are the most common challenge. I have immense faith in my manufacturer though. I've worked with them on over a dozen different projects big and small. They are very communicative about any snags in manufacturing. If any delays occur, I will make sure that backers know immediately. Transparency is my #1 priority.

- Inspections/grading is another challenge, but not too difficult to tackle. Grading just takes time. Every backer deserves perfect pins, so I usually take about 1-2 weeks to grade every single pin before shipping rewards.

- Package delivery delays can happen due to inclement weather, post worker strikes, or other unforeseeable events. I am happy to replace a package if it is marked as officially LOST by USPS on their tracking website. However, if your package is marked as delivered, I cannot replace it. Please make sure that your delivery address is a safe location to receive your rewards.

- International packages are another challenge. These do not have tracking once they leave the US. I cannot replace missing packages due to being unable to determine with confidence whether your package was truly lost or not. However, I am more than happy to resend packages once, only when they return to me in the post. As usual, backers are responsible for any customs fees their package may incur.

- The last and biggest challenge is always making Kickstarter a warm and inclusive space. Any hate speech, repugnant comments, ship warring, or otherwise unpleasant messages will be reported as violations of the Kickstarter TOS. If you have pledged to the kickstarter, and violate my terms, your pledge will be cancelled and refunded. Please always be kind. There are human beings behind this project.

- I will keep backers posted via the updates tab, and through my social media outlets! Please feel free to reach out to if you have anymore questions! 

- DO NOT REACH OUT WITH SOLICITATION MESSAGES. Solicitors will be reported, and subject to the law.

PRODUCTION: If there are any issues with the manufacturing process, I will be handling it. If something is completely unavoidable, I will be posting an update and gathering opinions.

COLOR DIFFERENCES: There may be slight color differences between prototypes/artwork and final versions. Any major changes will be posted. 

FULFILLMENT: We have a small team of 2-3 people who will be fulfilling the orders. We also frequently sell at conventions so please give us some time to ship your orders out. If there's any major delays such as interfering convention schedule, we will post an update notifying of delays. 

REFUNDS/CANCELLATIONS: Once the campaign has been completed, refunds and cancellations will not be accepted. Please only pledge if you are confident that you can afford to pledge!

The best thing about our project is that I am completely dedicated to making it happen.  As previously stated, I've planned out every aspect of our inaugural season, which will contain a modest two public concerts along with several collaborative events and public school residencies.   Below I will explain how fundraising is really our only challenge.  

Possible challenges for us include:

1. Venue selection
   - Venues for our concerts include churches, recital halls, universities, museums, and other public or private spaces suitable for music performances.  Many of them charge a fee for rental, and some require things such as insurance coverage or official non-profit status.  As long as we raise enough money, we will be able to cover the costs of renting a space and any associated costs such as piano tuning, liability insurance, etc.

2. Musician commitment
   -This is something about which I feel very strongly.  I decided from the very beginning of this group that I would always hire professional musicians and pay them fair wages.  This includes paid rehearsals, reimbursement for travel costs, and a high flat fee for performances.  If a musician is underpaid or asked to volunteer for rehearsals and/or performances, there is always the chance that they might cancel when a paid gig comes up.  With CMS-NJ this will simply not be an issue because we will be paying our musicians fairly.

     In the rare case that a musician has to cancel a concert, our area has no shortage of fine musicians who could come in at a moment's notice and put on a professional performance.  I also pride myself on knowledge of chamber music repertoire, which will allow me to adjust programs last-minute if necessary while maintaining the high standard of performance that our audiences will no doubt come to expect. 

3. Concert attendance/ticket sales
   - Generating ticket sales is always a difficult task for new arts organizations.  With CMS-NJ, we will have a robust social media presence combined with professional designs on our advertisements in print and on our website.  Flyers, emails, website, social media, and good old-fashioned word of mouth will all contribute to generating public interest and ultimately filling the seats in our concert venues.
