Either way no matter how much funding we receive we can not guarantee our appearance anywhere.

Katie and her team are passionate, educated and in love with SAO.  And where you have talented people following their dreams, you have success.  We might not attend every convention in world, but you will be able to purchase our CD and shirts any time and dance to one of our concerts!

It frequently happens that, once started by the composer, a work begins to take on a life of its own and develop in some heretofore unforeseen ways. When this happens, a project can take longer to complete.  We are currently on schedule for the finishing touches on the work to be done by the end of April, but it is possible that it may take a bit longer.  Our backers will likely agree that rushing a creative process can result in an underdeveloped work! However, the composer's need for sufficient time to perfect the composition must be balanced with the performer's need to allow the piece to "develop" during the learning process.  To accomplish this, Olga has been sending Matt sections of the work as soon as they are ready, so that he can start reading through them and providing his feedback as needed.   We are limited in our timeframe by Matt's concert at the Guitar Foundation of America Convention in the end of June, which means that the work must be finished in enough time for him to prepare it for the premiere.  It may be that the publication of the work will happen after its premiere, since Matt's fingering suggestions will be incorporated into the final score.

The main risks and challenges that lie ahead involve obtaining all of the right permits and licensing to have our space approved. With 7 years of experience and knowledge under our belt, we believe we're prepared to handle any setbacks and have already taken steps to prevent unnecessary delays. We have carefully taken the time to research and plan the building process, and we have a great network of supporters who are excited to help us accomplish our goal. RISKS &  CHALLENGES (SWOT analysis)

The biggest challenge we believe we will face will be sales of the DVD. 

The risk is we put money; energy & time into this project and then we don’t actually sell the DVD’s. 

As we are experts in the Yoga space we need help & resources in the marketing & PR space to take this product nationally and then globally. 



STRENGTHS

Two dedicated Kids Yoga experts with proven track record of running successful Kids Yoga classes in schools, children’s hospital, domestic violence refuge and after school classes.

The DVD has already been filmed, which involved 12 months of careful collaboration, planning, pre-production and $1000 already in pre-sales through personal connections only.

We also spent this 12 month period testing the product to our target market.

There is already a large interest from parents and some retail outlets.

We have already paid for the filming, costumes, set design, editing out of our own pockets

WEAKNESSES

Neither of us have background in marketing and/or PR

We need more  money to take this product out to the world

OPPORTUNITIES

There is nothing like this product in the market for Kids Yoga focusing on helping 5-7 year olds reduce stress & anxiety with school pressure & helping 2-4 year olds manage their emotions & behaviours. This DVD will also help our 8-12 year olds feel a sense of worth and confidence and to teach them their innate perfection.

High interest from parents from classes already taught and social media connections 

Opportunity for this to be involved in a school curriculum, hospitals, child care centres

THREATS

Competitors

Time

Lack of funding to continue with the project

With two years as a successful, growing business and years of professional coffee experience before that, Shark Mountain is ready for the challenges ahead.

1. QUALITY OVER QUANTITY

A lot of growing businesses struggle to keep the right proportion of quality to quantity. 

With a larger roaster in a new production space, our team will have more time to streamline quality control, dialing in on the perfect roast profile for each bean.

2. COMPETITION + SHELF-SPACE

There is intense competition for shelf space at many of your favorite local coffee shops and markets. Shark Mountain currently tackles this at many different levels. 

1. Providing exceptional quality at an approachable price
2. Selling two, unique products that showcase the transparency small-batch, local food
3. Approaching markets that are under-served—allowing these markets to experience coffee and chocolate at its highest quality and at an approachable price.
4. Collaborating with local businesses to create unique culinary products.
—We are active members of our community. Sitting around, waiting for coffee and chocolate to move off the shelf is not our style. We are always looking one step ahead for the next best thing to share with YOU!

Our project is completely a labor of love. For years, Meg has dreamed of creating this storefront for the community - and truly, a replicable model for all communities! She has managed her own art gallery and worked for decades in the health food industry. Meg is passionate about this endeavor and displays an incomparable tenacity towards this goal. She is competent in her abilities and complements this with a well-rounded team of goal-driven beings. 

One of our first major tasks is getting the word out. Our location is a prime spot in downtown Boulder with tons of foot and tire traffic. But we want to move beyond this! By connecting through social media with our friends and making new ones along the way, we plan to provide our house-made products in-store and online. To this end, we have reached out to our network of artists, owners, teachers, practitioners and more to bring our message and dream to a greater audience. Boulder has great local resources to tap into and once we are funded, we can move forward on our (social) media initiatives.

From there, our biggest mission will be to keep up with demand. Once people find our products at our prices, they will keep coming back. I mean Truly Raw, Organic, Sprouted, Minimal Ingredient, Small Batch Almond Breads and Milks for less than the price of the competitors? One gallon of our premium milk for many dollars under the price of a half gallon of the Pasteurized, Homogenized other brands and there really is zero guesswork. Additionally, we have tinctures found no where else, kombucha elixirs found no where else, and then a collection of hard-to-get, let alone hard-to-find items!

This is a place where we would gladly shop and we believe you, and so many more, would too!
Death, culture shock, sea sickness, pirates (not Johnny Depp) Bermuda Triangle, housing, a leak on boat, failed motor.

All artists face challenges when manufacturing enamel pins. The biggest challenge is quality. Pin molds can come out wrong, colors can be off, metal can come out looking tarnished or damaged. After producing two previous pin designs, I know what to look for and how to communicate my needs to the factory. No matter what, there will always be pins with minor defects due to their handmade nature. I intend to give my backers the best quality pins that I can sort from my batches.

If I am delivered a batch of pins that is just unacceptable quality, I will do my best to negotiate remaking them. This could cause delays. While I hope this does not happen, it's a possibility, and I hope backers will be patient if it happens. I will do my best to make the process as quick as possible should this occur, but I believe the factory I've chosen to work with will pull through for us!

The main risks we face are diseases and pests. Bees are living things and are not indestructible. Many natural events may cause the failure of a hive. This is the nature of the business and it is not 100% avoidable. In the event that your adopted hive dies we will try to provide you with honey from a hive that has not died.

I've spent the time, lots of my own personal money, and resources to mitigate the costs, risks, and challenges of a mini animation studio for others who would support and join. Animation has sped up dramatically due to software help. Possibly, the most important thing I need from you is solid, unflinchingly honest feedback.  I have never sold mail-order cakes before.  There are scores of unknown unknowns.  And frankly, I'm a hot mess on my best days.  I need to discover all the kinks in the process, before I try selling these to the general public.

Did all the frosting slide off?  Did you get a box full of crumbs?

Maybe it takes a LOT longer to make a batch of 20 cakes than I thought...

Does the pricing seem fair for what you get?  I'd be charging about 20% more (a full size 9-in round cake would be about $60 + shipping)

How does it taste?  I've been developing GF recipes for more than 5 years...  These cakes need to be as good or better than anything else you've eaten- if they are not, I really need to know.

This project is a game-changer.  Producing an opera of this scope and complexity is always a difficulty, especially in terms of schedule and budget.  The team we have assembled, however, has already been diligently working for months to ensure a boisterous and brilliant final product.  We've already seen many of the sumptuous costumes, glimpsed some genuinely funny moments of staging, and heard glorious singing. 

The most challenging aspect will be finding what fascinating culture to explore next!

The world of audio drama has become more accessible and globally renowned than ever before, and this is amazing news for projects like Jötunn, as it makes them all the more appealing. It also means that the standard to which good audio drama needs to be produced is very high. We don’t want to merely have a few voices tell a story with a little bit of music in the background. We want to create an entire cinematic world you can dive into every time you press play. That requires professional talent, high-end tech and innovative effects, and that therefore raises the budget for each episode to £7k.  Reaching our target will allow the creation of an amazing world steeped in Norse mythology, a genre that has found a place of high regard lately, but uniquely, you’ll be right in the centre of the drama. We have the team assembled whose credits have seen them in various high-profile projects already and they’re raring to go. We’re confident we can deliver something truly incredible.  Skål.

1. Logistics and transportation
(1) Delivery time：It needs to be determined based on the order volume. Generally, orders less than 1,000 bottles (15ml/bottle) will be delivered about 20 days after the end of the Pre-sale. Delivery time for large orders needs to be negotiated.
 (2) Logistics method：Because the product ingredients do not contain flammable and explosive ingredients such as alcohol, we have a formal FDA number, MSDS product inspection certificate, and can be delivered in small bottles, boxes, kegs, vats and other packaging methods through various modes of transportation such as express, air, sea and rail.

2. Agency, wholesale, OEM/ODM, MOQ
(1) The minimum order quantity for Pre-sale is 1 bottle (15ml). OEM/ODM will not be accepted during the Pre-sale period.
(2) After the Pre-sale is over, we will open the agency. The Cooperation model specific requirements are: oem and odm. The quantity should be more than 10,000 bottles. If the agency is wholesale, it only needs to meet the minimum order quantity. Our minimum order quantity is 12 products.

3. How to store the product
The shelf life of our products is 3 years。It is very important to use and store the nail polish gel correctly. Store the nail polish bottle in a dark place. Since gel products are sensitive to light, if the product is exposed to strong light or subjected to strong light source radiation, the gel will have a curing reaction. Therefore, do not put the nail polish in the open state too close to the LED lamp, so as to prevent the ultraviolet light emitted by the LED lamp from directly ir

We are committed to launching a 2nd hour of The Todd Huff Show, and we expect the biggest challenges will arise after the initial launch. But rest assured: we are preparing for those expected challenges as well.

In order for our show to continue to grow and succeed, we need to build a sales team. As it now stands, all sales are generated by me. And adding additional content to my plate certainly impacts my availability to secure new advertisers. 

So with the creation of additional content comes the need for additional sales support. (And to a lesser extent, production support, which is also part of the next phase of our plan.)

A sales team (and production support) will be funded through a combination of several things: 
* First, through continued growth in advertising sales. We're pleased to report that advertising sales have increased every year we've been in operation (since 2015). And those increases came in spite of the fact that I had a second business to operate until June 1 of this year. So we expect faster sales growth in 2020. We're seeing signs of this already in the 5 short months I've committed to exclusively working for The Todd Huff Show. 
* Second, through potential investors. We are currently exploring a couple of investor opportunities, and expect to have feedback on at least one of those opportunities during this campaign.
* Third, through the success of this campaign and other campaigns. 
* Fourth, through ongoing sales of Conservative Not Bitter Party memberships, which we will continue to promote on our show, social media, appearances, etc. 
* Fifth, through an increase in awareness that naturally comes from the purposeful activities we are engaged in (media, promotion, social, etc) each and every day at The Todd Huff Show.

I already know my following isn't all that big. The only way really for me to be able to reach out to fans of the show is that if you, the readers, are able to advertise this campaign to as many people as you could. Even more so if you know that there are Game of Thrones out there, please do show them this project of mine!

The risks that I may be facing are the normal ones when recording a project. Also, it may take awhile to mix and master my recording so it is up to radio ready standards. I think the sound engineers I work with are very capable. • All pins will be inspected before they are shipped out and all sales are final, but please contact me if you have any concerns.

As this is an all or nothing campaign that won't go ahead if the first funding goal isn't reached, there are very few risks involved! I am working with a trusted production company I've used for years and shipping will be tracked. However, there are always possibilities for delays!  

✘ Colour of pins may look slightly different on production
✘ COVID-19 may cause production delays 
✘ Defective pins may delay delivery, or need time to be produced again 
✘ Postage is not perfect! Please check your mailing address is correct and get in touch if you have not received your pins within 2 weeks of the latest estimated shipping time.

I will be posting updates and keeping you informed of any changes or delays!

We are very confident we can fulfill every reward to our backers. We already have much of the stock of supplies needed. As soon as we reach our goal, we will be ready to get the rewards out as promised. 
But with any ambitious project, there may be some delays in shipping as we work out the final supplies and numbers for this campaign. We don't anticipate any farm-related delays as things are growing and there have been no late frost issues this year. We think 2014 is going to be a great year!

Organic fruit comes in seasonally to local organic wholesalers-buying in season at peak times increases prices but also guarantees quality-a good job that jam lasts once it is made and sealed into a jar!

Production depends entirely on the supply of fruit-bad crops/bad weather are obstacles that could 'crop' up (pardon the pun)

Having the cash to enable me to buy in bulk at peak times will ensure I have the stock to continue selling products and not need to hang around waiting for the next glut of Strawberries of Blackcurrants to come into season the following year.

The great thing about Jams and Chutneys though, is that soft fruits are not the only produce which can be turned into delicious jams-more hardy plants such as chillies, peppers, onions, tomatoes which are more readily available year round can be used to ensure a good stock pile

Utilising local farmers is an aim of mine to ensure a reliable source, but many rely on wholesale purchases to survive themselves.

Since I am hand making each and every finger,  if I lose my hands I will no longer be able to produce them.

I am hoping to do the installation in June, but depending on how much other content I come up with in the next few months, it may get pushed back.  Seeing as it will be my first show and it will be a solo show, I really want to blow it out of the water.
Questions? message us on Kickstarter Or via our website https://www.kahodesign.net/contact

This project relies a lot on my Minecraft and gaming experience.  I've played Minecraft for over 4 years, built worlds and servers, installed mods and maps, and have designed and modified player skins.  I'm a first-rate, MC nerd. In addition, I will be doing the directing, editing, fx, and a lot of the other post work.  All of this has to get done within the next month...

To manage this, we are keeping the production small and are being selective with our shots.  With careful storyboarding and good use of time, we should be able to manage getting the project finished.

In addition, I am bringing in some great skilled partners such as Laura Cervin, DP,  who is experienced in all things video and grip related and can also jump in on editing and post as needed.

I also have great audio help with Carly Zuckweiler, who hosts a local audio geeks group and is a major talent with all things audio related, from production to post.

Finally, Ariane Mistral has worked on several films with me and keeps us on track, organizing all the details from pre-production through the end.

Between all of us, we have a large family of experts and professionals to reach out to for advice, support, and help because of our own histories working professionally.

The big challenge will in interweaving the two strands of material: my daily reality and the physical comedy version of it. It needs to flow and for the contrasts to be visually clear. Ideally one will be filmed on location and the other in a studio, to visually differentiate them. My experience on I Speak gives me confidence that I can make the two strands play off one another in editing.

When this project is successfully funded I shall be able to complete all stated deliverables well within the established time frames. There may be a slight delay in delivery of the DVD, but you will still get it long before Christmas!

Funds: This is probably an obvious one. This podcast will be free, but running a podcast is not free. Without the funds, the production and launch of this podcast and overall brand can be delayed for months in order to gather up the amount necessary to launch the brand. Empowered in Color is something that I have had on my heart and mind for almost a year now and from conversations with numerous people from all different spheres, it would be awesome to get this resource out there as soon as possible. What better time than the new year? 

Manpower: Currently, I am running everything myself with the exception of some video/photography help from my husband and (hoping to hire) two talented people to help create my podcast art and theme song. Besides that, I am emailing everyone, recording, and editing, and doing most of the marketing. With a day job, it can definitely be difficult to find the time to work on a project like this, but I am dedicated to helping people make the valuable connections they need and will be able to get it done as long as I have some accountability. I also hope to hire someone to help out with some of the tasks in the future, especially when we start hosting in-person events.

If this project is funded that will immediately kickstart me into booking studio time at one of my favorite studios. There is always the possibility of some slippage in the the schedule but I think it's completely realistic that I can finish the actual recording by the end of August 2013. These are short pieces and the final CD will be closer to 30 minutes in length than 70 minutes. A collection of solo mandolin pieces will need only minimal mixing and mastering. I will be sure to keep all participants fully informed if things are delayed.
Getting the payment cleared from Kickstarter and getting the prints to you before the 25th of December will be tight, but so far our print and distribution have been solid through some tricky times.

There are always risk associated in the recording of a live performance. There can be unforeseen challenges and circumstances that arise. In order to minimize this risk, we may arrange for multiple recording sessions.

Once we have the master disc we will try to find a label to distribute and promote the CD.  In the current climate this could be difficult, but we hope that including previously unrecorded music will help.  If we can't on this occasion release the CD on a label we will be looking to distribute and market it ourselves as effectively as possible, perhaps with professional help.  The benefit of this approach is that we will receive all profits from the sales, and maintain complete control of the look of the CD.  As well as selling the CD on our website and at concerts, we will be using the disc as a 'calling card' to promote the group widely to concert series, festivals etc.

For further information about the precise budget for the project please contact Emily Ashton - emilyashton1000@gmail.com
There's absolutely no risk at all since all photos are taken, edited and ready to be sent. You can support us with confidence.

We will be able to launch this coming fall, only with the raised funds. If there are technical issues, this may delay the process but we fully intend to have three tales for you to hear in November. A tale will be posted each month.

I have confidence in ensuring that every process goes smoothly and the pins should reach you perfectly. I have also owned a business previously and am experienced in packaging, shipping and updates.

Therefore, I would say that the two biggest risk I would face is not having this Kickstarter fully funded and shipping delays as overseas packages may take a longer time due to customs. Nonetheless, I will update accordingly should there be any delays.

Should you need to contact me, do email me at pinfixmail@gmail.com and I'll be glad to answer your questions!

Crafting a 10-episode narrative podcast that is both enlightening and entertaining is no easy task. The development process is much more like creating a documentary than a typical discussion-based podcast. Actively seeking provocative and personal stories, investigating every facet of the mystery, constructing compelling scripts, and interviewing experts on a wide gamut of issues from history to philosophy to science, is all part of the process necessary for us to attract and engage people from all over the religious spectrum.

Our team is 100% committed to making and releasing Hinge in its entirety to the public. Whatever it takes, we're going to tell this story! We've already begun building an extensive database of stories and interviews and crafting the general outline of the show, as well as building a community a community of invested listeners and contributors. But, if Hinge is going to make a meaningful impact in bringing people together across our country, we want to take the time necessary to offer the most captivating series we can. 

The question therefore is not will Hinge be released, but *when* will it be released? And the more help we receive, the sooner you'll be listening to our story unfold. So please, PLEASE help us make it happen!

*ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE.*
*Video music: "Wings" by Eden Fox

The goal of this Kickstarter crowdfunding campaign is to be able to pay the crew involved on the project as well as they deserve it, and to cover the other expenses involved in the production. The crew of Quartet is very dedicated to the project, trying their hardest to make sure that everything goes as planned. Creating an artistic project that involves film, music, and dance is a big challenge within itself, but carefully selecting a competent group and dedicated people, I’m confident that this will work out very well.
We are looking forward to share our rewards with all of you and to involve you in the process of creating this short film!

El objetivo de esta campaña de crowdfunding en kickstarter es ser capaz de pagar a los miembros del equipo involucrado en el proyecto como se merecen, y cubrir el resto de gastos relacionados con la producción. El equipo de Quartet está totalmente involucrado en el proyecto, haciendo todo lo posible para asegurarse de que todo salga como está planeado. Crear un proyecto artístico que involucre cine, música y danza es un gran desafío en sí mismo, pero seleccionando cuidadosamente un grupo competente y gente dedicada, estoy segura de que todo saldrá adelante.
¡Estamos deseando compartir nuestras recompensas con todos vosotros e involucraros en el proceso de creación de este cortometraje!
Should this project not be successfully funded, we may struggle to achieve our aims of making the next season better, more extensive and more valuable for listeners.

The biggest challenge with this project will be in post production.  I have already booked the recital hall and engineer.  My producer has arranged all of his travel plans.  Taka and I have performed this repertoire already twice and have been rehearsing regularly since.  The only delays could come with editing and production, but I have arranged things so that August and September will be devoted to finishing the project.  I then plan on replication of the discs for early October.  This timeline should make the finished product easily deliverable by December 2013.

The major challenge with this project is getting the funding at the right time and having them printed and shipped ready for Toronto Pride weekend! Stickers can be printed incorrectly and will not be ready for Toronto Pride, but can still be reprinted and disseminated at a later time.

We understand that if we are not able to reach our goal everyone will be refunded with sincere apologies' and hopefully the next pin will do better!!
we also understand that if we get more orders than expected it may take longer for us to package and send all the goodies but will try our hardest to send on time.
some pins may be simplified or a slightly different colour to the intended design but will still look beautiful.
Based on the past success, we don't feel that there are any challenges that would prevent us from successfully completing this project AND advancing further.

Lee Actor is an accomplished composer who has met his deadlines for years. Lee has the time set aside, the necessary computer file back-up schedule, and the ability to complete this commission. Barring some sort of incapacitation, this project has every chance for completion once the funding is in place.

With any new business you are always taking a chance. This is one reason I turned to Kickstarter. No one likes to fail but with this platform you always have people supporting you and your idea . I would like to project a Fall opening.....that way I can take advantage of all local harvests.  I know that may create some issues with getting all necessary pickling/canning done in time.  If the funding is successful it would help alleviate time constraint obstacles.  I don't believe 
getting all the necessary permits will be an issue but sometimes paperwork takes longer than usual.  I am taking a chance here. I know any backer that supports me is investing in me an my idea. That makes me want to work even harder.  Flexibility with people I want to supply me helps. I have known most of them for years.  My obligation is to address any obstacle or prolem as soon as it becomes evident. Work to find solutions to issues as quickly as possible. Use my knowledge of dealing with issues as a positive for this vision. The place I am looking to lease may have some setbacks but as far as I know the space will be available soon enough to get any modifications done inside so that my work can begin.

Risks and challenges

Since all the PleasureTown staff (including our awesome interns) work day jobs in addition to producing the show and since none of us are professional reward fulfillers, there might be a slight delay in delivering some of the rewards. But, rest assured, we'll seek out experts and professionals to ensure that everything gets delivered in a timely manor.

Also, there is always the minuscule possibility that we will not win another award. However, know that the shelf you help us purchase will still be put to a wonderful use regardless.
There are not any high risk possibilities due to this being a small scale project. However, we are prepared for any challenges that may come up during the shoots.

Our craftsmen are well versed in their craft and we try to make sure, that we achieve optimal utilization of our resources, the most important asset being; the time. All preparations aside, there are always chances of delays, inefficiencies and uncertainty due to the long list of variables like, material sourcing, panel drawing and quality checking.

We will make sure to try our best, that none of the variables affect our backers and we deliver our promises, the way we made them. if there are instances, where it is nothing but impossible to avoid the delays, we will keep you posted and sufficiently updated.

Trying to bring the outside environment indoors poses a logistical challenge. One of the biggest risks we face during production is keeping our sand floor and various other natural elements contained. With careful planning and team effort we hope to see this executed carefully and smoothly.
No RISK - only 1970's music.  "Who say's you can't go back..."

Reward does not come without risk, but we believe our adaptable and diverse approaches provide a greater chance of success. We’ve met so many challenges successfully at the onset -- securing FCC approval, building permits, studio establishment, initial equipment purchases, and community involvement -- that if this campaign is successful, paying our fixed expenses for 2016 and building additional studio capacity pose very few risks.

However, there is always chance for the unexpected. Bottomline worse-case scenario would be if ever a crushing FCC violation came into play. As a small operation without sizable corporate funding (and, therefore, at our own personal financial risk), we are always cognizant of this, and so we take extensive preventative measures and reinforcement to ensure compliance throughout our wide-ranging programming. Our coming acquisition of a professional broadcast profanity delay will also help reduce this risk.

And finally, perhaps our biggest risk would be a lack of community engagement and support -- as programmers, as listeners, as underwriters, as donors, or as friends of local arts and culture. That is the risk many in the community face, but it is with the committed belief in this project that we continue.

In addition to this fundraising campaign, we hold a great number -- and wide scope -- of fundraising events throughout the year. These events are often in partnership with other small local groups who play viable roles in the Rochester arts scenes, and are not only successful financially, but they broaden our range of engagement and inter-connection with the community at large.

Due to the nature of our production, many of the risks are associated with the connectivity of cast members.  Sending lines back and forth over the internet, especially when the files grow in size, becomes more and more tedious.  However, we have already standardized our turn-in procedure, so this is not a big problem any longer.

Though a good portion of the planned budget is for our actors, and the actors that will join the crew later down the road, the rate that I have decided upon is very minimal, and does not give our actors the opportunity to work on the production full time.  However, I have already discussed this with our core members, and will be informing future members of this to prevent any confusion or delay in release.

I have run and completed 4 successful kickstarters in the last 2 years, I have been running a small online store and selling at conventions for years. I have experience with budgeting and handling merchandise.

The funding goal includes a small buffer in case of change in exchange rate, unseen taxes/delivery fees or extra costs for envelopes and other necessities, so there is very little possibility of financial issues backing up production and delivery.

There are common risks that can cause challenges. One of the main one being the uncertainty with Covid shutdowns. Also sometimes there are unfavorable delays that can arise during production. As a company we commit to communicating to you if any problems with shipping or production occurs. We greatly appreciate each and every one of you. We will work very hard to ensure that we provide quality products for you and that we operate in excellence, transparency, and integrity. Thank you so much for supporting BCNovaMarie.

We are confident that we will complete this project swiftly and efficiently.  The equipment, talent, and studio are booked and on hold, and we have a motivated crew eager to make it all come to life. 

One challenge that we must remain conscious of, however, is keeping this space safe and respectful. We are aware that we are touching on a very sensitive subject and hope that by offering our support and perspective we can promote progress and knowledge together.

We are confident in our skills and that we can create the DVD. We believe we have accounted for everything.
We will be updating the status of what is going on with the project periodically. Our aim will be to let people know about any changes as they happen and to give everyone a constant stream of info on the schedule and progress we are making.

The beginning of the production was already faced with some difficulties, as some people were no longer able to be involved with the show, including my choreographer. I am fortunate to be working with some very kind and helpful people, so even if they are leaving they can suggest others who would be interested in taking their place. 

Originally it was meant to be a live performance, but my tutor and published author, Mimi Thebo suggested it could work really well in a multimedia format, as I already had planned to use poetry and music within the show.

We're also going to be working outside and with the British weather in mind, this may change our filming schedule in some ways, but we are driven enough to carry on.

Oh, no risks in telling people you're gonna make a SPOOKER film and develop it in horse poop.  :0  

Actually - I make handmade "Art Films" all the time, usually one a month. Only difference is I'm doing a Narrative.  The risk that all artists take is in YOUR PERCEPTION of my work, once it's finished and presented. 

The thought that YOU will view my work, and JUDGE IT for your self (and judge me and all my friends connected to this work) - fills me with a great responsibility.  It drives me to produce the very best that I can.  I may utterly fail in this regard. I think though, that a percentage may like it.

All my life I've told SPOOKER stories to my family at campfires while camping. Yes, young nieces and nephew who my sister says laid in their sleeping bags scared. In that crazy scared-but-safe-entertainment that Spooker stories are.  And the next night at campfire, they're begging Uncle Kurt for "more Spookers!"  And my sister rolling her eyes, and sitting back to enjoy.

And that's what I'm doing for you. Telling Campfire Stories. With crappy illustrations!  

- Kurt <3

We are limiting the number of cases manufactured for this project so we can get them made and shipped in a timely fashion. Outside of that, the only thing stopping us would be flight delays in getting Myke from London to Atlanta, but we have a three day window to get everything recorded.
This may suck. I don't think it will, but no one ever does. I promise to do my best to create a podcast that entertains and informs.

EN:
The book has already received financial support from Ophavsretsfonden, Kulturelt samråd Thisted and Grethe & Jørgen P. Bornerups Fond. I will also finance a substantial part of the expenses myself. 

Your support on Kickstarter - thank you! - will make it possible for me to produce a total of 500 copies of the book. Once you all have received your copies, the remainding books will then come for sale in a few, handpicked bookshops as well as online. 

If the campaign exceeds the set goal, it will be possible to produce more copies of the book. This means that I will be able to promote the book further and make it available to a wider audience.

TIMELINE

April-May 2021: Kickstarter campaign

May 2021: Print by Naranya Press

June 2021: The book is published

July/August 2021: Books, prints and postcards are shipped


DA:
Bogen har allerede modtaget støtte fra Ophavsretsfonden, Kulturelt samråd Thisted og Grethe & Jørgen P. Bornerups Fond. Jeg dækker også en væsentlig del af udgifterne til bogen selv. 

Når du støtter bogen her på Kickstarter - og tak på forhånd! - bliver det muligt for mig at få trykt 500 eksemplarer af bogen. Når jer der har støttet bogen har modtaget jeres eksemplarer, vil resten af oplaget være til salg online og  i udvalgte boghandlere og butikker.

Hvis Kickstarterkampagnen indsamler flere penge end sit mål, vil det være muligt for mig at trykke et større oplag af bogen. Det vil give mig mulighed for at nå ud til et større publikum. 


TIDSLINJE

April-maj 2021: Kickstarter-kampagne

Maj 2021: Tryk af bogen hos Naranya Press

Juni 2021: Bogen udkommer

Juli/august 2021: Levering af bøger, print og postkort

This book is slated to be off the printing press by end of June. 
The risks for this book not publishing are low.
This campaign is functioning as a pre-order method.

While we're confident the book will be publishing no matter how our pre-order goes, we do recognize that there's still opportunities for delays, and or slight changes in the exact parameters of the final product, though we don't expect there to be any such issues.
With any project, there are always risks but as I have done manufacturer and material research, I am fully confident that this project will run as smoothly as possible.

✦There may be delays in manufacturing due to the Covid-19 pandemic, or other unforeseen circumstances, but backers will be kept up to date in any case. I have already accounted for some minor delays in the production timeline, so if all goes reasonably well we should not encounter any difficulties.
✦Final product may look slightly different than the digital art due to color differences in monitors.
✦Shipping may be slower than estimated due to the pandemic.

These designs are mock-ups, so the finished product may look a little different. I have produced pins for thirteen previous kickstarters and had no problems. I know what to expect, and I'm pretty certain everything will go smoothly. I have everything set up with the manufacturer and I have had pins made by them before.

The challenges that we are currently facing are raising the funds to publish the magazine, to help with this we are collecting some adverting from parties related to the industry but we hope this crow funding will help cover the rest of the costs for the magazine and the launch itself. 
We are also facing challenges with the deadline quickly approaching.

-Traveling always comes with surprises, but that is why you plan ahead, have AAA, and buy insurance for your flight and the things you ship. In this case, I will also be traveling with all of my primary printmaking tools and other supplies I'll need for creating. I am still weighing my options as far as whether I fly and ship everything or drive myself and my supplies halfway across the country. So far, neither one is cheaper and both present many opportunities for things to go wrong.

-I sense homesickness in my future. Thank goodness for phones, Facetime, and snail mail.

-Shipping a shadowbox piece would be an adventure, but it is one I am will to take.

We don't actually anticipate any hang-ups. All of the work is completed and we are all lined up with the printer to produce the prints. The only issue is the finances to cover the expense of the printing. We have set our goal for €2000 in 30 days and with that we can get the ball rolling. If we reach our goal we will do everything in our power to get you your reward as soon as humanly possible!

1) Increase in costs if one of the producers cannot complete the project close to their given estimate. In this case I'll do my best to move finances around to bring the project to completion, with the most likely result being a slight delay in delivery.

2) Completing the writing of the book and shooting the videos could take longer than expected, although I have listed my expected delivery date as 3 months later then my personal goal.

3) And of course I could die. In this case I asked my wife to finish the project by interviewing past clients, apprentices, students, close friends, and beloveds who could easily collectively write out and share the teachings and insights from each card. She agreed and I am happily not planning on this.

All Presti members have already individually recorded CDs of their own projects.  We will be applying our past experience to this new endeavor, and hope and expect to achieve only the highest level of ensemble and sound reproduction. 

With members living, respectively, in Alaska, New Mexico, and Texas, two years of touring will be applied to this recording. We endeavor to maximize our recording time, keep our interpretations fresh, and to work for the highest level of precision.

Called "a major force in the New York early music world" (New York Times), our artistic director, Jolle Greenleaf has successfully organized the Green Mountain Project for 3 years in a row in addition to many large and small projects for TENET, New York's most exciting early music vocal ensemble, to uniformly excellent reviews from the New York Times and other major publications. 

The musicians have been contracted, the venue is booked, and we've already begun selling tickets--we are all set to go!  We just need fund to honor all of our commitments, and we are working hard to ensure that happens!

Starting any distillery is a risky undertaking. Anyone can learn how to operate a still, but without a well-organized and executed strategy things will not get very far. The biggest challenge is just getting the doors open. If I can garner enough support to do that then I'm almost to the finish line. With your help I can make that happen.
No potential risks.

We know that this entire project needs to be completed in a relatively short space of time. Our team have experience of working to tight deadlines, and are confident that this can be delivered. We have previously collaborated on other projects and know our working methods are compatible. 

Our stretch-goals will take place outside of the initially set timeline, with an aim to be completed by 2015. In the event that we are unable to deliver any of the stretch goals unlocked, remaining or surplus funds will be donated to a sanitation organization (TBD.) In this case all backers will be informed and will have the option of a refund.

If the project does not meet its targets the project will go forward in a scaled down capacity, with what time and skills the team are able to donate.

I used a Kick Starter campaign to fund a teaching trip to Ernabella, Australia in 2012. In addition to being a life-changing experience it was a great introduction to the Kick Starter community and fund raising process. 

During the beginning part of the campaign I felt the surge of excitement that comes with a new project. I thankfully reached my goal and set off on the trip. Once I arrived in the Outback I ran into my first set of challenges. The rewards for the campaign included collaborative pieces created by myself and the Pitjantjatjara artists that I visited. I had not anticipated the difficulty in shipping art from the middle of the Outback to the United States. Armed with that knowledge, I have planned extra time into the budget for my current Kickstarter campaign to deal with shipping. 

Another challenge that I ran into was fund-raising fatigue. The beginning of the campaign was filled with encouragement and "high-five" experiences. Months later as the last of my rewards were distributed I was exhausted. To help counteract this sort of fatigue I have planned a gentler time line for this campaign. I now know how long it takes to fulfill rewards so I have readjusted my expectations. I think this will help me not to burn out early in the campaign. Fundraising is a lot like distance running. You have to start out slow so you can save energy for the final push.

With the backing of Unicorn Publishing, we are confident that 'Generations: Hastings Fishing Families' should  be ready by September 2021, if not earlier. However, with Covid-19 still an issue, there is the chance that there may be unforeseen delays in production of the book and delivery of rewards. If there are delays, I promise that I will keep in touch to make sure that every backer receives their reward.
If the project is funded, there will be no risk as the funds will be available to print the book

The biggest challenge is securing the funding needed to meet the book's production deadlines for release in fall 2021. Delays in the printing process are always possible, but Daylight is a first-rate publisher with a dedicated staff and record of success. If this funding goal is met, I am confident the book will be released on time and I will keep all contributors updated on the production process.

Our first and biggest risk will be to reach enough Kickstarter backers within the timeframe of our campaign.  It is essential to this concert that we meet our goal, for without the necessary funds this event will simply not be possible.  We strongly believe that working musicians must be compensated appropriately for their time and efforts, and we will do everything we can to spread the word of this campaign in order to meet our goal.  We also fully realize the importance of finding the best venue to suit the needs of our concert series, the mood of our events, and the size of our audience.  St. Paul’s has been wonderful to deal with as our preferred venue, but without the appropriate amount of backers, we will not be able to secure the booking.
 
After our finances are squared away, we will be faced with the challenge of reaching an audience for our concert.  As a brand new concert series, we will be almost starting from scratch as we start to build our audience.  Our past concerts have been held in a 50 person venue, but we are being much more ambitious with this concert, and will attempt to fill a venue that seats 300 people.  While we will not have a budget for marketing the event by traditional means, we will be working hard to increase our presence in the community, and hope that the high profiles of our performers and conductor may also help draw the attention of a new audience.

We've been involved in numerous recording projects as musicians and producers, so we know how this works.  This recording follows a successful Kickstarter project we did for my first solo CD last fall, so we also have experience with working with backers and making Kickstarter fun and successful.
This project requires a lot of people to come together to create it, so there's always the risk that someone could have a personal emergency or a hurricane or snowstorm could postpone it, but we've put so many hundreds of hours into this already, that there's no way we're not going to make it happen.
May have been better off unreleased, but will release film if enough demand and financial support are acquired.

Honestly, there are not that many risks associated with this project as it's one that no matter what happens, will be made. AND IT WILL BE RELEASED!
And if some people are worried about the project not being seen then YOU NEED NOT WORRY ABOUT THAT! 

Just on my own, I have a reach of around 100k-200k each month and on top of that the film will be submitted to around 20 different film festivals so you can bet your bottom dollar that the film will be seen!!
The only risk that we foresee is not reaching our funding goal.  We have set in place the infrastructure and manufacturing plan to begin production early 2020

As this situation is still unfolding the timeline/budget may have to be adjusted as events unfold,  If such events should come to fruition we will plan to launch another campaign to continue this story as a part 2 addition.

Our Team will be working remotely for the majority of this production with a small crew traveling to select locations for filming and interviews.  In the Event that travel restrictions tighten production may be delayed or the script may be amended to accommodate.

To mitigate risk, I plan on having an agreement signed by the individuals featured in my videos. 

By offering companies free advertisement within my video will help with the challenges that may arise of trying to convince local businesses to participate in my planned events. 

Offering an incentive of participating in my videos and promoting the videos across my social media platforms will help generate the buzz needed with people tuning in and viewing my videos which will help further my vision in creating a greater lasting impact within the community.

The main steps for this project to be successful are: the completion of the pieces, the rehearsals with the musicians, the organization of the concert itself, and the recording of the CD. Since we started planning this project a lot in advance, all essential pieces of the puzzle are pretty much in place: the composition of the pieces is already underway; scores will be delivered to the performers by the end of October 2012. The performers will have about a month to rehearse the new pieces. The concert is scheduled to take place in San Diego on November 30th, 2012. The venue is already booked (a very nice recital hall at UCSD), and the event will be free admission. The recording is also scheduled for January 2013. Allowing for another month and a half to finish up the production of the CD, the estimated delivery date is set to March 2013.

How are we qualified to realize this project?
One of the composers (Tania Lanfer) is a graduate student at UCSD and is taking care of concert promotion and organizing. All four composers have plenty of past experience with concert organizing: Tania has helped organize numerous events at UCSD; Bruno actually worked as concert organizer at CCRMA (Stanford University) between 2010 and 2012; and before coming to the USA, Fernanda and Bernardo helped organize a number of new music concerts in Brazil.
As for the recording: we have already arranged a professional recording facility for January 2013. The musicians will spend one or two days (depending on need) recording every passage as many times as necessary. The composers will finish the mixing in February and finally make the recordings available both in CD and digital download format in March 2013.

In summary: thanks to all the work already put into this project so far, everything is ready to happen. We just need to raise the funds to pay Gnarwhallaby for their work!

Having already worked with the Das Karussell Orchestra at the Brucknerhaus, I feel confident that they are the perfect orchestra for me to record ORCA with. I have heard other classical albums made with this orchestra that have been recorded at Brucknerhaus and they sound stellar. We have taken all the appropriate measures to insure that the recording equipment and engineers used are consistent with achieving a recording of the same highest quality. Every recording session has it's list of challenges, but we've made all the necessary arrangements to minimize any bumps in the road. This will be a challenge, but a very manageable one that I feel very confident will be handled with the utmost level of professionalism. 

The goal fund of $25,000 will cover the necessary recording costs of the actual session itself, but nothing else. From a risk/challenge perspective, this is our biggest one. Mixing and mastering will need to commence thereafter, and usually there are considerable funds that are required to make that happen. Fortunately, I have my own studio that will be mixing and mastering in, so I will be able to effectively manage costs associated with this process. Also, I feel very confident in my abilities to effectively mix and master the album as I have had plenty of experience in my studio. In fact, I just mixed my most recent full length rock album 'Harakiri', that has received great reviews for it's audio quality. Additionally, I will be working with the same engineer who helped mix my previous live album recorded with an orchestra, "The Elect The Dead Symphony". We have plans to mix and master the album upon our return from Europe after this concert on October 28, and the timeline that we have mapped out to complete the mixing is very manageable.

We are also working towards finding a well respected classical music label partner to up with for the official release of ORCA. This has been an ongoing process that is showing much promise. Since no official agreement has yet been made, there also exists a challenge here with respect to timeline of official release date of ORCA. However, I have taken this into consideration and have allotted for the appropriate tentative release date of June 2013 for the physical cd of ORCA to be delivered. If no agreement can be reached, I have a backup plan. Since I do have my own record label in Serjical Strike Records, I would self release ORCA myself. This is also a very manageable challenge as I do have years of experience releasing records and have the ability to produce and release my own music as physical products.

We're in pretty good shape with this project.  We've successfully recorded 2/3 of the material; the director and the recording engineer have worked together successfully in the past; and the duplication company (Oasis) does fantastic work.

Traveling to a new country can be an intimidating experience simply because of the language barrier and culture shock.  We hope to communicate just as effectively to audiences and students (in masterclass form) who speak a different language and have had different musical experiences and backgrounds.  

Mary and Josh are overcoming this obstacle by studying Spanish with Pablo.  Although the words we use might be basic, the global language of music and our willingness to learn will provide for an enriching concert and cultural experience.

Red Nebula is an ambitious undertaking. As a college thesis film it presents an exciting opportunity to flex our creative abilities and create something not just passable, but something we can always look back on with pride. The genre demands a level of creativity and imagination rarely seen in your everyday drama.

Setting - Red Nebula takes place on the space shuttle Erebos, a derelict Earth shuttle carrying dozens of lottery winners to their new lives on Paradise. This means the building of miniatures, space shuttle interiors, props and some fancy camera work.

Style - To make it feel real we need the right equipment for the job. This means rentals for cameras, lenses, sound equipment, as well as aquiring props, costumes and all the little details that will bring this story to life.

Manpower - Everyday I wish I could just close my eyes and manifest this film. Yet I can't. It is going to take a team of people that I can trust and rely on to make this thing happen. People like my Cinematographer, Dylan Kaplowitz or my amazing Assistant Director, Pavlos Christou, and my stunning Producer, Alannah Fehrenbach. All of whom need at least a square meal a day.

Join us in proving my Professors wrong by making this film become more than just the dreams of a crazy Brooklyn College Film Student.

We've faced many challenges since the start of the development of this product. The primary challenge was finding a manufacturer. There were no U.S. manufacturers or engineers who felt they could design an ink pen small enough to contain a USB along with an ink pen and stylus.

Invisivision is a product entering a very competitive market place, in both film and advertising. Though there are a number of obstacles ahead, we are prepared to overcome them using a variety of tactics.  We have identified the niche of inexpensive visual interactivity which creates an avenue to engage viewers more effectively.

However, the method in which Invisivision operates involves the use of a stereoscopic environment, effectively making theaters with stereoscopic-enabled displays a dependent variable in our success.  

Being that our primary target involves feature films, RealD, MasterImage and Dolby Digital are some of the major players in the stereoscopic entertainment market who become direct competitors of PipeDream Interactive and Invisivision.

We've secured strategic partnerships with established industry entities which have provided us with invaluable insight into the entertainment field.  Regardless, we still face the challenges of encouraging user adoption, solving technical issues such as "ghosting", and creating movement in an industry which can be notoriously slow to react to change.

All of these can be combated by convincing one Hollywood studio to produce a feature film for these glasses.  A key factor is that these eyewear are used in the right type of film - one that delivers the best content for the viewer.  We've already had requests from two major studios to show them a quality demo.  You can help us get there.

We're not new to this - and having previously taken a project successfully through Kickstarter, we are very aware of the numerous risks and challenges that creators face. 

Ada is already at late stage in the development process, and we are working with experienced industrial designers and electronic engineers to help mitigate risk. As a company we have experience in manufacturing electronics in China, as well as the logistics involved in shipping to our tens of thousands of existing customers around the world. 

That said, all projects face risks and challenges. These are some of the blips on our risk radar: 

FCC and CE testing. The devices have been developed to meet the emissions criteria for both FCC and CE marking, but until the final prototype is complete we will not be able to do the actual testing. This may mean we need additional revisions to the electronics to pass the tests, which could cause delays. 

Sourcing. We have several quotes from manufacturers, but until we know how successful this Kickstarter project is, we can’t get final costings and finalise our negotiations with the manufacturers.

Manufacture. We have extensive experience in manufacturing products in China: both our first Kickstarter products and our popular Triggertrap Mobile Dongle are manufactured there. However, manufacturing in the Far East isn't without risks. One key challenge is quality control. For Ada, we are producing fixtures that will extensively test the devices as they are manufactured. As manufacturing starts we will keep a very close eye on quality, both in person, and through experienced QC inspectors. 

Finally, we promise to keep you guys in the loop every step of the way, so you know how we are getting on!

I have been a machinist for many years; I am largely self-taught. I have always had an interest in the Luger; my fascination has more to do with the degree of precision required for such a utilitarian item. I started making wooden rubber band shooters when I was still a boy, and the Luger was a natural subject. The iteration in the photo was from a small production run of rubber band shooters that I was commissioned to build over fifteen years ago. Since then, my talents and abilities have grown enormously, and the advent of inexpensive, desktop CNC machines have made the required, repeatable precision much easier to achieve. 

The challenges will be in working to tolerances of .001 in a material that is not stable, and prone to warping and distortion when machined to thin sections. I believe I have achieved a method to stabilize the wood to make such precision possible and repeatable. I will investigate the feasibility of creating wooden coil springs that are functional; this is something which no one else to the best of my knowledge has ever achieved. These are the risks and challenges that I will face when it comes to actually making the parts.

Greater challenges lie with documenting and writing up my experiences into something that someone would actually want to read. I am not a writer, and have never published a book before, but those skills will be necessary to completing the project. The end goal is the construction of the physical object, which will be donated to the Joe Martin Foundation Craftsmanship Museum in California, and the documentation of the construction along with a coherent set of instructions and photographs which will live on for eternity in cyber-immortality long after I am gone.

The biggest risk facing this project is with regards to time and scheduling. The expectation is to shoot the film over a period of three months with most shoots taking place on weekends. If an actor is scheduled for a given weekend and cancels for whatever reason, this impacts the schedule. If this happens several times (with either the same or different actors) the schedule will be drastically impacted.

There may be opportunities to make up for the lost time. Options might include scheduling time during the week for actors who are available during the week. This is one possible way in which time can be made up, but the entire crew as well as Lee Lin must be present as well, which could be problematic.

The expectation that scheduling may have to be modified at a moment's notice is critical so that if problems arise changes can be made ensuring that each weekend can be used for a shoot during the three month window.

To help prepare for these issues, schedules will be established with up to three optional weekends for each shoot. If a cancellation becomes necessary (things do happen), optional alternative time frames will already be available so that communication can start immediately to try to rework the schedule and avoid as much lost time as possible.

In addition, some arrangements will be made for backup actors and crew, so that if there is a drastic cancellation there may be a tenable solution that can be developed relatively quickly. As further protection, an extra month (beyond the target three months) may be allocated for filming just in case things go wrong.

Most funding is directed towards the extremely difficult manufacturing process. There is no set cost of how much a specific component will require, due to the uncertainty of its final quality. Fortunately, most challenges have already been overcome in the past 15 months, and we are now focused on the opportunity of moving into engine test phase. There are currently no foreseeable challenges that would delay this project, aside from lack of funding.

1. During the test, we can see that a particular satellite subsystem requires changes or substitutions. Our team has all the necessary experts to modify the contents of the device.
2. After the satellite production, Roscosmos (the Federal Space Agency) may require some revision of the documentary part of the project, to allow boarding to the launch vehicle. Our Project Leader is in a close contact with the manager of the small spacecraft launches, so he can solve this situation.

Kickstarter asks: How are we qualified to overcome any adversity of this campaign?

Mobile Recon Systems has dedicated a great deal of time and expense to bring the KittyHawk quadcopter project online. We have established gold standards for assembly and production of the KittyHawk units. There are strict guidelines in place to ensure supreme craftsmanship in every Kittyhawk we build.  Mobile Recon Systems has implemented buffers and margins to ensure that we can deliver KittyHawk units by April 2016. We have the experience of a successful KickStarter campaign.  Please refer to our previous success at: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/2011448493/lens-guard-protection-for-dslr-lenses/description.

We have carefully selected our vendors and production facilities with redundant backups, many of these we have worked with in the past with major success.

Although, events can happen that we cannot anticipate or control, such as postal strikes and natural disasters, the typical delays in a project are supplier and shipping related.  This is why we have identified multiple supply channels to enable us to adhere to our planned shipping date.  International shipments will be affected by the local customs regulations and schedules. 
 
We will keep all of our backers up to date and send out notifications of parts arrivals, component progress, milestone events and shipping schedules. There are some risks in this project. This is a one-shot flight, we do not have another chance if the experiment doesn't works correctly. We are confident about our stabilisation system because we already tested it in nearly the same conditions as the suborbital flight pattern.

For the other systems, we did not have the opportunity to test them on a zero-G flight, and anyways, the weightlessness time given in this type of flight is too short to conclude beyond 20 seconds of time. We will make a lot of tests on the ground, to make sure that these systems will not fail on the suborbital flight. (these tests includes vibration, temperature and acceleration resistance)

If we raise enough money for this project, it is possible that we book a new zero-G flight to test the final experiment before the suborbital flight, if we have any doubt on the behaviour of the experiment while the suborbital flight. This zero-G flight can also be an opportunity to compare the results of the experiment with the results on the ground and on the suborbital parabolic flight.

one final thing, at the end of this whole text : Thank you !

We have solved most of the more difficult challenges. Primarily the design stage is complete and we are very happy with the outcome. According to those in the aircraft design industry, the ThunderStruck X-2A ticks all the boxes. Our own spreadsheets indicate that this craft is sleek enough to stay supersonic for about half a minute and will reach Mach1.5. The craft will be about 3m long and it will have a mass of 15kg. The force on the nose cone will will be the biggest issue with it reaching about 35kg during the maximum deceleration due to thickening density of the air at lower altitudes. The craft will move to horizontal flight at about 13km altitude and it will slow to some hundreds of kilometers per hour. It will fly at about 200kph until it lands on a runway. A drogue chute will slow the craft and stop it from veering off the runway.

Add to all of this, the amazing team that Jason has around him. There are 10 advisers with everything from space experience, IT, Radio systems, 3D design, CAD, flight analysis, rocket systems and much more. I will be telling you about each of them in the regular updates. 

Even DSTO has offered us access to their test systems for our craft. We can shake it, bake it and test how to make it! Even the radio systems are able to be tested inside a chamber that stops all outside radiation from being an issue.

Even the massive zero pressure balloons will not be an issue. Jason and I (his father) launch weather balloons to the stratosphere all the time. We hold a record in that we have launched 23 flights and recovered all 23. Two of them were in Croatia where we had to avoid the landmines still in a large part of the countryside.

In all we have covered all foreseeable disasters and have enough expertise and support to overcome any others. We are excited to find other like minded people that may join our team, so let us know if you have some special skills.

We have manufactured dozens of functioning Static Displacement Field Drives generating 10-500 Millinewtons of thrust. We have also manufactured some light-weight disks that will become the foundation of our Quadcopter Drive Kits.

Our internal testing of these devices has been conducted on on custom-built equipment. We are in the process of arranging 3rd party testing at NASA. The risk is that these devices don't work when tested by a third party. 

Other “breakthrough” devices that have been recently tested by NASA have failed to generate measurable thrust. These devices were predicted to have had thrust numbers in the micronewton range. Thrust numbers in this range are very hard to measure to a level that can't be rationalized away, just like the Electric (aka Magnetic) Scalar Potential has been rationalized away for the last 100 years. Our devices are producing thousands of times more thrust than these other devices. Thrust numbers at these levels will make it hard, if not impossible, to rationalize away the thrust that our devices produce.

Another risk is reward fulfillment. We now have been making these devices for over a year and we have our suppliers already making the components for these devices. The more devices that we are able to assemble, to fulfill our rewards, the cheaper these components are going to be to us. Plus, the more that we make, the easier it is going to be to get the bugs out of our designs. But this is no guarantee that we can make any more.

We currently have five Static Displacement Field Drives with thrust numbers between 100-200 Millinewtons. These five drives will be used for our third-party thrust demonstration test and will be the source for the first five drives sent out for the $10,000 level. These five drives are drives that make history, just as the Wright flyer did 100 years ago. Just think--if you had the Wright flier and how much it would be worth today. Any devices that are ordered beyond the initial five devices will be manufactured using the same process as the initial set. However, we may experience a delay in the manufacture of components for any/all devices manufactured after the initial set.

As with all space projects there are risks and challenges far greater than for projects on earth related to the task of placing a house on the Moon. This is the normal state of things in space projects and a part of what makes them so fascinating. 


1.   Missions to space

All missions to space face the same basic challenges. The environment in space is very different to what we are all accustomed to here on Earth. On Earth the atmosphere blocks out radiation from the Sun as well as from deep space and filters out much of the UV-radiation in the light from the Sun. The presence of air tends to even temperatures out, locally leading off heat produced by machinery for instance and globally giving us the chance to enjoy a hot summer night also when the sun has set. How things behave under these conditions is well known simply because we have a lot of experience personally of course but also scientifically and technologically. Moreover, on Earth you have access to equipment that you use and have the possibility to fix things when they wear down from natural wear and tear or do not behave as you expected or wanted.

In space things are different, the sunlight with its unfiltered UV-content, and on the Moon the surface temperature can vary from 120°C (250°F) during daytime to -150°C (-238°F) at night. Under these conditions, with temperature variations stressing the structure, UV breaking down the surface materials and electronics unprotected by an atmosphere from radiation and when it is not possible to fix things that go wrong, equipment has to be carefully designed.

The colour of the house is of particular interest. The colour red has not been the colour of choice for space missions where white, black and and metallic surfaces dominate because of their thermal properties. Red is a particularly tricky colour to use in space, many pigments have a tendency to break down when exposed to sunlight. For this reason we are particularly glad to have Falu Rödfärg as a partner. Falu Rödfärg has 250(!) years of experience of exposing red pigment to sunlight as a producer of exterior paint for housing.

All of the above factors will be addressed using space proven materials and designs which include secondary systems for moving parts and electronics acting as backup. The Moonhouse technical team all have unique competencies in developing the house. 
 

2. The construction of the house  

With all the electronics and the mechanics – the house is in many ways a great technological challenge. Not least since this will be the first time a house – a self-constructing house – is placed on the Moon. This whole procedure will take between 5-15 minutes, until the house is fully unfolded. The process of self-construction is deliberately prolonged to eliminate the risk of unwanted surprises. The gravity on the Moon is one sixth of gravity on Earth, which is sufficient enough to allow The Moonhouse to stand and remain on the surface of the Moon. There is no atmosphere on the Moon, and therefore not a flutter of wind, which is why the house can remain still despite its light weight. 

 
3.  Running short of backers 

The Moonhouse is one of the world's most ambitious crowdfunding initiatives. The goal is to fund 15 million USD from various crowdfunding venues before November 30 2014 to make sure that the house is ready for take off with Astrobotic in October 2015. If the project has not been funded by November 30 2014, all funds (minus applicable administrative costs) will be returned to the backers. But if enough people join, we will together have changed history in space and the understanding of what people can achieve when working together.  

The goal for this Kickstarter project is 250,000 USD for Prototype 1. If we reach this goal of 250,000 USD, but The Moonhouse fails to reach the overall funding goal of 15 million USD by November 30 2014, all backers will be reimbursed of their pledged funds, minus applicable administrative costs. This would include 5% to be paid to Kickstarter, and costs to be paid to Amazon as described at https://payments.amazon.com/help/Amazon-Flexible-Payments-Service/Creating-Managing-Your-Account/Amazon-Payments-Fees. 

If we do not reach the goal of 250,000 USD for this Kickstarter project, all Kickstarter backers will be reimbursed their pledged funds, also less administrative costs. All proceeds generated via crowdfunding will accrue in full to The Moonhouse.


4. Legal structure   

Mikael Genberg is the creator of this Kickstarter project. For handling The Moonhouse art project in the United States, Mr. Genberg has founded an American company called House on the Moon LLC. House on the Moon LLC is based in Washington, D.C., and is a wholly owned subsidiary of Luna Resorts AB, a Swedish company that is itself wholly owned by Mr. Genberg. The sole purpose of House on the Moon LLC is to realize The Moonhouse. While it may become necessary at a later stage to engage one or more paid employees, currently House on the Moon LLC is, and is anticipated to remain, staffed solely by volunteers.

This Kickstarter campaign has been initiated and will be executed by Mr. Genberg through House on the Moon LLC. In order to meet Kickstarter, Inc.'s administrative requirements, Andrew Skowronek, a volunteer employee of House on the Moon LLC, will act as House on the Moon LLC's United States contact for Kickstarter, Inc. (Mr. Genberg resides in Sweden). Mr. Skowronek is acting on behalf of the company in his capacity as a volunteer employee of House on the Moon LLC. All funding will remit to a House on the Moon LLC Amazon payment account, and, if the goals are met, to a House on the Moon LLC bank account, both of which are controlled by Mr. Genberg through House on the Moon LLC. House on the Moon LLC is solely responsible for all aspects of this project.
