Crowd Cookware’s The Tasman is the sixth campaign we launch on Kickstarter within 3 years. So far, we’ve managed to design, produce and deliver chef-grade cookware with and to our backers. All according to - and sometimes ahead of - schedule. We learned a lot and built on that experience during this next adventure!

The Crowd Cookware Tasman is one of the newest requests received from our crowd. Similar to our Buccaneer skillet, our knives, the Wigbold and two earlier cookware campaigns, we’ve run a pilot production round with a manufacturer who meets our high-quality standards and produces pans like ours on a large scale for premium brands. Our crowd tested The Tasman and now we have confirmation: the Dutch Oven and grill is ready for mass production. We’re good to go!

We want to note that we are currently living in a transport and material crisis and that this could seriously affect our timeline. But as true pirates, we believe we can win this battle and get The Tasman to you in time!

We will keep you posted

Consumers’ feedback on market mask brackets:

Pros & cons of regular mask brackets
O Advantages

1.	Breathable even after prolonged use

2.	Do not stain easily

3.	Reduced saliva odor

4.	Inexpensive and disposable

X Disadvantages

1. 	Fall off easily

2.	Expose mask reducing protection

3.	Hard to store

4.	Form mask marks easily

5.	Uncomfortable after long use

6.	Strong plastic smell

7.	Abrasive

8.	Hard to wear/remove

9.	Stain easily, unwashable


Pros+ without the cons = Just Easy by Junsih

1.	Reusable and eco-friendly

2.	Does not stain or ruin makeup

3.	Matte black finish, no yellowing

4.	Easy to wear, hard to slip

5.	Magnetized pads for adding scent

6.	Odorless food-grade silicon

7.	Non-abrasive, reduces mask marks

8.	Secures mask retaining protection

9.	Drawstring bag for storage, collapsible

10	Breathe easy without stuffiness

Having worked to publishing and distribution deadlines for many years, we're confident that we will be able to get the books delivered around the world by November - we have booked a slot with the printer, and we're hoping to rally some troops to make sure we get the print editions wrapped up along with the thank you notes and sent out as soon as we receive them.

The biggest risk that we foresee is that having made the fundraising target as low as possible, we have very little room for manoeuvre should we run into any unforeseen costs. However, should the unplanned occur, we have the revenue from subscriptions to the online version of Unmapped to help us get out of any jams.

The magazine industry is a challenging one, but by offering just the first issue rather than subscriptions, we are confident we can deliver. 

TOAST Magazine is independent and ad-free, so we are not reliant on advertising revenues to make it happen. We are also optimistic that our experience in the publishing world, our subject matter and the quality of the publication will result in success. We believe there are enough like-minded individuals in the UK and around the world to help this project flourish.

Some of the rewards are dependant on the finished film. We have a set timeline for the completion of the documentary but if things were to take longer some of those rewards would too. The team promises to keep you updated regularly about the process.

Making a documentary on such a specific topic, the difficulties of doing CG in the 80s, is not something you see every day. With the support from the French National Center for Cinematography, and hopefully yours, this dream is at hand. We've been waiting for the pandemic to finally ease down, and the crew is fully vaccinated to travel, and ready to shoot as soon as December 2021.

Our biggest challenge is that of any crowdfunding project...reaching our audience! We know you're out there, we just have to get to you. 

Distribution:
Like any filmmaker we would love to see this movie get picked up by a distributor so more people can see our hard work. The best approach for this is film festivals...the downside to this is festivals don't want your film if its widely available. That being said, festival screenings may cause delays in fulfillment. 

Sustainability: 
We here at Static Age Productions believe in being good stewards of our planet, and as such we strive to be as environmentally sustainable as possible. This leads to some aspects of fulfillment, like physical media, being a bit more complicated to create. We do everything in recyclable packaging with as little plastic as possible. We also pay for carbon offsets when traveling.

Having all of production in house in the United States means that I won't have issues dealing with global logistics. Additionally I already have the tooling and workholding finalized for the tappy tap. As with all hardware projects there is potential for delays, therefore I've set a generous delivery time to compensate.

The Cyber Stand™ has no electronics, so there will not be any delays caused by electrical parts.

We have worked extremely hard to make this product ready for full-scale manufacturing and fulfillment, but here are what we see as the risks and our plan to assess them:

The greatest challenge in this endeavor is the amount of labor involved. The Journal has published 25 issues, totaling 89 articles and 44 book reviews. The digitization process requires scanning, running text recognition, editing metadata for the PDF containing the full issue, breaking the issue up into individual articles, indexing (titles, authors, keywords, and subjects, which requires skimming through and in some cases reading through the full article), and editing the PDF metadata for the individual articles.

Then the web element requires uploading, creating web posts for each article and full journal, copying and pasting all the indexed material, creating thumbnails, and finally publication.

The second phase requires converting the PDFs to a text format, editing each article to verify the accuracy of the text recognition and correcting errors, manually converting the footnotes to a particular online journal format, formatting section headings, and again creating new posts with all the indexed material.

Thankfully, the College students living at Don Bosco Hall are more than capable of successfully completing this challenge with your financial assistance.

But I feel extremely confident that won't happen, because I have very good taste in zines. They're going to sell. They are!

Hello Everyone!! My name is Lance Hall CEO of Sweet Azeep and I've always felt that in life we must persue our passions no matter what! So here I am, going all in! I was enrolled in school working on obtaining my degree in education at CSUN when my mom was diagnosed with Stage 4 Colon cancer in which she passed away soon after. Cancer sucks, but more importantly it showed me life is just too short. We never know how much time we really have, so why don't we spend it doing the things we love? I had a business concept I had been sitting on and through reflection felt that "why not" pounding deep within. I've decided to try my hand at entrepreneurship as its always been something I wanted to do but never thought it'd happen. So here I am, determined to succeed when it seemed like i would never get a chance at seeing my business plan through. I'm calling for help to achieve my goals as I push towards the ultimate goal, a store front in LA, and hopefully many other locations in the future! 

This is my first business venture and while I'm new to most of the challenges that come with owning a business, i also am very determined to see my plan go through. Raising initial funding to have our custom griddles made for the cakes is a major hold up due to the expensive nature of Aluminum casting, but once we have the money needed we can truly make the desserts that i know people will love and crave. Im completely confident in all our recipes and flavor combinations that have been phenomenal in their own different ways. I feel confident in gaining the exposure to promote and sell the Peezas, but need the funding for the initial start of something great.

Of course, we can't talk about risks without mentioning our friend, COVID-19. If COVID-19 interferes with the making of this record, it will push everything back, not cancel it. 
If for any reason I have to postpone my studio time, backers will receive an updated timeline of when they will receive rewards and when the record will be released.

Opening a restaurant is full of risks: location, overhead, lack of traffic, long leases, high rents, running out of cash before renovations are complete, not being able to get licensed... OOH, I just scared myself! But nothing worth doing is risk-free and sometimes you just have to jump off the cliff and hope your parachute opens (at least that's what Steve Harvey said). 

We're confident the time is right to give Lukes' Soul Food Cafe a home. The cost of opening a restaurant in most cities is high and DFW is no different. So our mission was to get the best possible location for the least possible expense. First, we participated in an incubator being planned by our city of Desoto and bought marketing materials, did a pitch and PowerPoint presentation in June and got in! Unfortunately, we were told the incubator building would open on July 1st, but it's been delayed until (maybe, possibly, could be) October 1st and we really think it's going to be next year or longer. So we've decided to skip the city politics and delays and try to make our restaurant happen on our own, well, with your help.  

This is why we've had to be smart about the how and the when. We retained the services of a commercial real estate agent in July and started looking for a building that would work for our needs and was affordable. We wanted to keep overhead low so we could keep our prices as affordable as they have been. We knew we couldn't afford to do a restaurant build-out which is basically taking an empty shell and turning it into a restaurant; ain't nobody got time (or money) for that! 

We told our agent we were open to "fixer-uppers" because we were willing to put in the sweat equity and elbow grease needed to make this happen so we could decrease costs further. We've been fortunate enough to have "patient capital" invested by our parents (thanks PawPaw & Mama!), but there's a LOT that goes into opening a restaurant, let me tell ya!

So, as you've seen in the video, we found a restaurant in Mesquite that used to be a Sonic and negotiated a very reasonable lease amount and term. As you can also see from other videos, the place needs some serious TLC and that's gonna cost more m-o-n-e-y. And then there's the equipment that we need because ain't no frying fish without a stove or deep fryer! My wife, the accountant, is a for-real-for-real accountant and she is CHEAP (all caps)! We're looking for used everything, even stuff that I have to tinker with to make work again (I'm handy like that)! We want to make sure we spend our coins wisely. We know that we set our funding goal low but we're really (really, really) hoping that you, the best family ever, will push us way past that so we don't run out of money before we buy trivial things like, oh I don't know, a commercial stove.

It took time to get to this point and we're going to be cautious and take our time as we scale up for growth. With your support, we know Lukes' Soul Food Cafe can be a successful part of the community and, eventually, create jobs in the community! We have big plans for our brand, including making sure you can find some of your favorites, like our delicious chicken tenders, right in your grocer's freezer! 

We know you can't wait to come sit down and enjoy a great meal BUT we have to walk before we can run, so one of our ways of being frugal and getting the best deal on a lease is we're going to start small and grow into a dine-in restaurant space LATER. Y'all we talking pick up and delivery only, come get it and go, for now! Once we gain some momentum, we will definitely be getting y'all a drive-thru window, but baby steps. Show us some love and we'll show it right back by growing bigger and bringing you along with us!

This is a labor of love to pay homage to our heritage and our beloved family members who taught us everything we know about cooking good soul food. There's going to be plenty of blood, sweat, and tears to make this happen; plenty of hard work and hard decisions; plenty of sacrifices and long hours. But it'll be worth it in the end because there will be plenty of good food and good times, plenty of laughs, and plenty of love too. We're ready if you are! We're going to share it all with you every step of the way and we might even need your help with some of the tougher decisions; we're not finna (that means "fixing to" or "about to" for y'all good folk not from the Dirty South) get caught out here in these entrepreneur streets with no guidance! We don't know how it's going to turn out but we DO know two things: 
1. the food will be awesome
2. our customers will be treated like family because, to us, that's what y'all are! 

If you're down to ride with us and see our hustle, then buckle up and let's go get it!

When it comes to dealing with goods, there are always potential risks and challenges. There may be issues with manufacturing, time frames, delays, not enough funding to unlock certain items, etc.

I have made various products such as enamel pins, vinyl stickers, magnets, and more. I have reliable manufacturers for my products to ensure a smooth production process and quality products and will communicate with them and continually update you on the process.

Manufacturing: While I will communicate with the manufacturers as carefully as I can, there is the possibility that the product outcome may be different than anticipated. These include pin quality, faulty pins, minor or major mistakes that may require the manufacturer to remake the product, which can take a lot of extra time. Some designs may be edited slightly when the manufacturer proofs the images. I will be sure to check the quality of the pins and other products before I ship them to backers. If the products must be remade, there will be a delay in shipping time and I will communicate this with all of the backers if that were to happen.

Shipping Delays: There is the possibility of delays or damaged products during shipping. While I will package goods in the safest way possible, I can't control what happens after it is shipped. If backers receive any damaged products, please contact me so we can sort things out. With shipping delays, there isn't much that could be done beyond being aware of COVID-19, unforeseen weather issues, international shipping delays, etc.

Funding: Kickstarter is an all-or-nothing funding platform that gives creators a shot at paying for the production of merchandise while allowing backers to receive rewards for helping fund their project. There may be the risk that this campaign does not meet all of its funding goals, meaning that if you pledge in hopes for a product that is never unlocked, you will not receive said item(s).

*Note that refunds will not be issued under any circumstances once production has begun, as funds go directly into production. By pledging, you understand and are willing to pay for both the items you pledge for and the subsequent shipping fees.

Even once we're funded, one significant challenge in creating this magazine will be continuing to find enough high-quality content and contributors. We know a lot of funny people and we've already gotten a lot of interest in being involved. We're confident that our commitment to actually paying people for their work will further attract the talent we need. We believe that once people see a full issue of Paperweight and understand its potential, we'll hear from a whole new set of excited contributors.

Another challenge for Paperweight is born out of the fact that we're aiming to explore the possibilities of comedy on a tablet.  If we're doing our job correctly we'll be building some things that have never been built before.  The prospect of solving new problems is tremendously exciting, but it also puts some additional pressure on us to choose the appropriate platform or framework to help us bring this project to life.  We need to be able to create content quickly with a reasonable amount of effort, but not at the expense of interactivity and flexibility.  We've put a lot of thought into this already, but still expect to lose some additional sleep over it before all is said and done.

Maybe our biggest ongoing risk is that people won't actually be willing to pay for content and Paperweight won't be sustainable for the long-haul. We're hoping you'll help us prove that's not true. We believe that comedy, joy, and an innovative interactive experience are worth paying for. We hope you value people who make you laugh. In the words of Marco Arment, a developer, writer and thinker we both admire, we "support writers in the most basic, conventional way that, in the modern web context, actually seems least conventional and riskiest: by paying them to write."

One final risk is that the upcoming new season of Arrested Development is really good.  If that is the case, we'll be MIA for a good chunk of time when the season hits Netflix.

Why are we asking for your support?

My husband Mark and I did most of the production work on the 28 programs in the current series…. finding families, researching, writing, shooting, editing and marketing the shows and teachers guides ourselves. But since Mark developed Alzheimers, we've assembled a skilled production team to help us continue this vital work.  We’re asking for your financial support to produce new shows as well as to put the series in a position to continue into the future.

We had originally hoped to deliver three episodes, but had to roll that back due to COVID19. 

Currently, we're editing two programs and writing teacher's guides on Colorado and India, and we plan to complete these projects by next quarter.   A program on Sweden has been delayed by Covid19, and we anticipate producing that show once conditions allow. Once we're able to complete that or a similar episode, all donation levels will receive streaming access. 

We plan to use this time to find potential non-profit partners who can help us locate families with good "sustainability stories", and to develop distribution and marketing for the series.

Our history of navigating production challenges for 28 programs on 56 families all over the globe demonstrates our ability to successfully reach our goals.

Our subjects' lives change quickly, so being able to film them now is of utmost importance. Two of our dad's just got out of prison and are spending more time with their daughters, and one of our subjects just got diagnosed with a terminal illness. Staying positive and resilient, our subjects have asked for us to come back to be part of these stages in their lives.

Product life-cycle carbon emission modelling is a notoriously complicated process. By using online resources and consulting with practitioners in the field, we’ve been able to gauge an educated estimate. We then tripled it. That’s the amount of carbon we will be off-setting as part of our Environmental Commitment.

Nothing makes Charlie happier than to know someone is happy with his products. Trust us when we say he will do everything in his power (natural powers are unfortunately out of his hands, along with supernatural) to get a wonderful, quality product to his customers in the shortest time frame.  That being said, due to the pandemic, manufacturing timelines have been affected. We are working with manufacturers who are behind some of the biggest backpack brands. many of who launched on Kickstarter, so we have the utmost confidence in their work. 

Thank you for your support so we can continue supporting others doing amazing work on the ground.

Please be aware that, due to current COVID-19 situation,  there might be shipping and delivery delays.  I will make sure to keep you updated on the international situation during the Kickstarter campaign.

Risks and challenges

On time in full delivery.  One of the reason I chose to focus on pins is that, right now, shipping anything too large worldwide, its a bit of a challenge. So, whilst things are taking a while, I have found stickers and pins get through the system easily and quickly, I've learnt how to package them not to snarl up the machines. I get disappointed when things I order don't arrive on time, so that's a big deal to me. I have the experience to deliver to you, if there are problems and delays, I'll be proactive and communicate to you, keeping you in the loop.  Quality of product.  The most important thing to me is that my products are right first time, every time. Quality of products is one of the biggest challenges when upscaling production. I have been digitally art working for production and manufacturing for over 10 years. I've handled every kind of difficult vendor. That said I have worked with this manufacturer for a long time, they have never let me down. If the unthinkable happened, I have secondary manufacturers I could call on to rescue the project. I personally inspect and pack every single pin. I'll be the one handing them to the post office. You can trust the quality.  Production Delays  Unforeseen circumstances happen, but I've pre-empted some of the most common problems to keep things running smoothly. We have already worked with this manufacturer before and we've already had the artwork pre-approved. If we do get any holdups, we'll communicate out to supporters. I've built the timeline with a fair bit of flexibility.  Overwhelming Orders. In the exciting situation we receive and exceptionally large amount of orders, our manufacturer has assured us that they will be able to fulfil production. We will fulfil orders first come first shipped. If this causes delays later on, we will communicate.

New start-ups, restaurants and bars are always not easy to get off the ground and make a success - and generally the hospitality industry is a notoriously risky enterprise. Using all of the experience of everyone involved - which includes industry-leading knowledge of fast-casual dining openings, as well as openings of new bars, our risks from the outset are reduced.
Furthermore - the concept is of low-cost design/creation with good contingency factored in, and is of low-cost operation - exposing the business to far less risks once cash flow is introduced and making it more flexible to any changes needed.

Like any other new business there are risks and challenges but rest assured, we are prepared:

If our Kickstarter campaign is unsuccessful, we'll still serve wine and beer at our restaurant. Just not as much. And you won't be able to enjoy it in an awesomely-renovated space.

The Market: While wine not may be new to Cadiz, there is not a "wine Bar" within the region: Consumers' tastes are changing in favor of domestic and foreign wines.  The Wine Bars industry has enjoyed a stellar run over the past five years and has taken advantage of an evolving hospitality landscape. The industry, which consists of bars that primarily serve large selections of wine rather than draft beer and mixed drinks, has comfortably outpaced the Bars and Nightclubs industry as a whole.
Planning: As a military mother and past Director of Operations, Debra is no stranger to strategic planning. She has left no stone unturned: from the cost of local wine and beer to the appropriate foods to serve, to the service expectations- we've done our homework.

The Team: Our staff will be carefully selected and trained to make your visit to our establishment perfect. As a woman-owned and -operated establishment, we will pair our professionalism, attention to detail, and work ethic with a the highest level of service.

Integration: We will strive to partner with other local businesses to provide, entertainment, marketing, and a venue for the entire community to enjoy. We believe in supporting local business and will use as many locally-sourced ingredients as possible in restaurant and Wine Bar.

Thank you for your time, your support, and we'll see you in the New Year!

Last year, Contrivers’ Review published a pilot issue. We learned a lot from the experience. We navigated the challenges of online publishing and clarified our vision for the journal. Over the year, the underlying web technology on which the journal is built has improved markedly. We’ve published several top-notch essays on topics like the labor market in universities as well as reviews of new books of popular and scholarly interest. Now Contrivers’ Review is poised to move forward. We’ve learned a lot from this process and are excited to use our network of writers and thinkers to address the question of technology.

The primary challenge to any publisher is economic. The industry is at a crossroads as established brands attempt to monetize their digital presence; meanwhile small, independent magazines—like Contrivers’ Review—are appearing everyday funded largely through charity. The realities of the market put us in competition with many other worthy claimants for your donations. And our commitment to paying writers a fair compensation puts additional pressure on our long-term fundraising. Such concerns are broader than the scope of the project outlined here, however, and our project is deliberately limited to avoid the existential questions that plague the publishing industry. 

Another challenge of this project is in highlighting the intersections and overlapping dynamics of diverse fields. Finding someone to write about a topic for which they have a great passion is not a problem. However, we envision a diverse and vibrant set of voices contributing to our conversation. We're taking steps to broaden our network by recruiting more editorial staff and reaching out to other communities and online clearinghouses. Then, we, the editors, will be responsible for asking writers to sculpt their arguments in productive, dialogical ways.

In addition to long-format essays, Contrivers’ Review publishes “responses” meant to continue and enlarge discussions with new voices and ideas. Remember that Contrivers’ Review is digital, and while the technology issues will be published as a piece, the conversation around those articles will continue to grow over time.

The goal of printing this first edition of TRANSGRESSOR: SELECTED WORKS is to not only create a beautiful object that celebrates people who push boundaries, but to also provide Transgressor with a modest revenue stream.

Every dollar we make selling this printed collection will go right back into the project. If it's a success, we will continue to print a collection every third digital issue. If the printed collection doesn't fly off the shelves, we will continue to make the digital magazine as we have been, and keep thinking of other creative ways to support the work.

WHAT YOU'RE HELPING TO COVER WHEN YOU DONATE:

Printing costs:

Printing is expensive, which is part of the reason why Transgressor began as an online publication. With TRANSGRESSOR: SELECTED WORKS, we want to shoot for the moon on our printing process, while staying true to our grassroots approach.

We plan on making a first-run of 1,000 copies of TRANSGRESSOR: SELECTED WORKS 1-3. At more than 200 FULL-COLOR pages, the collection will be printed on high-quality matte paper and perfect bound. It’s important to us that we create the most beautiful printed object we can.

Production + Design:

We believe that it is important to pay people for their time and talent. Even though this is a collection from previous issues, there has been and will be many hours spent making this book. From brainstorming the best design concepts to researching the right paper, everything that has been done so far has been for the love of the project. We are putting a lot of thought into the creation and presentation of this collection, and it will show.

Distribution:

A large part of why we chose to bring this project to Kickstarter is that it functions as a pre-order system, the idea being that people who are already supporters of the online project get to be the first ones to get a copy of the printed collection for as little as $25.

But we are also really excited about the idea of the printed collection being on the bookshelves of our favorite bookstores. While we’ll hand deliver the collection to Farewell Books here in Austin, we’ll have to mail it to Printed Matter in NYC. At 200+ pages, the collection is substantial, so shipping is a real cost that we have to consider.

Also, Amazon and Kickstarter each take a bite, so we had to factor that into the whole as well.

Growth:

We also have plans to revamp the website to create a more flexible, dynamic home for everything that Transgressor represents. We are also going to add an online store so that you can buy the collection - as well as work by our contributors - from us directly.

Every dollar from this campaign and the sales of the printed collection will go directly back into the project as a whole. We’re currently hard at work on the fourth digital issue of Transgressor, which we are making with no budget to pay our talented contributors.

This campaign is just one step we are taking toward being a self-sustaining project that doesn’t rely solely on the enthusiasm of our contributors in its creation.

No Kickstarter project is without risk, but we've worked hard to assemble the right team and sourced the best possible suppliers to mitigate any unforeseen challenges that may present themselves along the way. Still, here are some potential risks that are out of our control and our thoughts on them.

SUPPLY CHAIN. Sometimes a machine or tool breaks. Sometimes a factory loses power for a day. Sometimes we get the wrong parts or materials in. These things happen from time to time and can affect how long it takes to build our products.

MANUFACTURING. Creating a wetsuit involves a lot of craftmanship. Compared to other textile products, wetsuit production requires many man-hours and can’t be fully automatized with existing technology. We also aim to deliver a high quality product, so we take care of every single unit produced. This takes time and the real lead times might vary. That is why we prefer setting a realistic delivery date instead of promising unfeasible shipping dates. 

FULFILLMENT. 2 wetsuit colors. Women and Men models. 10 sizes each. The add-on. Several Rewards. This can potentially be a hell of combinations to prepare all orders. Anticipating this challenge we have partnered with experts in the matter. Nonetheless, delays on receiving all order items might push back the shipping of your order.

SHIPPING. Global shipping and warehousing logistics are mind-boggling. Hence we outsource that stuff to experts. But even the experts aren't immune to weather, port congestion, the Suez Channel being blocked by a vessel and other uncontrollable factors.

PANDEMIC. These days is harder than ever to make accurate estimates. The Covid-19 pandemic has disrupted any well planned project. We are slowly getting better worldwide, but we can’t, unfortunately, promise things could go backwards anytime.

We will be working with manufacturers who have years of experience delivering excellent products in tremendous quantities. There will no doubt be some surprises along the road, but any obstacle will be addressed by combining our internal knowledge with external expertise, and an overall goal of making the best possible product for you, our beloved customer. 
Any pledge amount brings us one step closer to our goal. Join our journey to protect the oceans by clicking the ‘Back This Project’ button at the top of the page, or by helping us spread the word by sharing our page.

WhiteClouds has created two projects on Kickstarter before the 3D Marscape campaign. The two Kickstarter campaigns were both fulfilled on schedule. We communicate with backers at least once a month through regular updates. We take our backers' commitments incredibly seriously and have since we launched our first campaign in 2013. While backing a Kickstarter will never be totally free of risk, backing a WhiteClouds Kickstarter is as close as it gets. 

This project is unique. We will need to make some critical investments in machinery and training to fulfill the campaign; however, these investments will be sufficiently covered by the funding goal we've set. The designs and production processes have been exhaustively planned and tested by us, and the dedicated craftsmen who will be carrying it out are trained and ready to go if the project is successful. All the manufacturing will be taking place here in the United States at the WhiteClouds manufacturing facilities.

Work has already been done to source materials. As the project goes on and we can determine the scale, we'll begin finalizing material procurement and placing preliminary orders as we're able. We have planned for success and do not anticipate any issues sourcing hardware, lumber, packaging, or any other materials.

WhiteClouds has its own in-house shipping department. We have been shipping delicate 3D printed materials for eight years and have learned all of the tricks-of-the-trade to reduce any shipping problems. Final delivery will be handled by standard couriers (USPS, UPS, FedEx, DHL, etc.). With the challenges of COVID, we will do our best to make sure your package arrives safely and on time, but many times that is entirely out of our control.

This is the first ever kickstarter project for us. We knew what it will take to bring this project to a successful completion and has worked tirelessly in the last months. 
At Freemax, producing top quality products is the foundation of our work. We take sustainability seriously. We don’t like that products get replaced year after year. We think that products should be purchased just once. So all our products are designed to last. With that said, We have vigorously tested each part to ensure that our product holds up under the mostrigorous industrial settings. It is a time-consuming and expensive process but we wanted tomake something exceptional that could be passed down for many generations to come. We create tools and products that empower people to take charge with the simple turn of a wrench or twist of a screwdriver. We want to move tools forward, and bring about the next generation of useful instruments.

The only risk we foresee would be shipping a little bit later than the estimated dates shown if the project is extremely over-funded. We have planned in extra time but if a production or shipping delay happens, we will update everyone know about it ASAP. The images shown are also functional prototypes and the minor design elements or dimensions may be slightly adjusted during mass production to ensure we produce the best smart-motion screwdriver for everyone.

Having already made a small production run, the risks are fairly minimal.  I've spent months finding the right suppliers for making the covers and anodizing the aluminum.  I also machine the body of the wallets and assemble the final product in house, so that is entirely in my control and I have the process streamlined.

However when scaling anything there are risks and challenges.  The first production run was fairly hands on and time intensive.  The production method for fulfilling the Kickstarter orders will be more hands off and automated.  The only risks and challenges will be in automating the manufacturing methods - CNC machining multiple wallet bodies at once rather than one at a time, and bending the covers with a press brake rather than a hand brake.

I have experience with both of these techniques, so any challenges I face will surely be overcome with some thought and effort.

RISKS - Apart from the immediate risk of impending bankruptcy and selling my virginity online, the main risk is with ending up with a half-a**ed productions due to a lack of funding. Like Sinatra at the end of Von Ryan’s Express - So close yet so far.
I’ve done this before. I sold a kidney to fund an album, Antidote,  years ago, and it was just horrific as I was then an amateur using a gifted amateur. (I feel sorry for the songs. "Why did we get him?", they cry.)
I was then scammed in 2017 when I was conned by a fake producer in Shikoku, Japan who said he was had a world-class recording studio. In the boonies.  He had no online presence or credential but I convinced myself he was eccentric genius living in the great outdoors as I was so desperate to finish songs for the 10-week World Tour that summer... but he turned out just to be a kid's English teacher in a one-horse town. His world-class studio was a bedroom with a cardbox box sound barrier. he then made me hire a mountain cabin so we could “record 24/7” but then invited his family to stay for holiday while we were there. A  total scam. I would advise anyone to really do due diligence correctly when recording,
I lost all band funds but learned a hard lesson and  have since only used real bonafide world-class pro studios and musicians:
Karma Studios (Jamiroquai, The Libertines/Babyshambles)
Krabi Road Studios - Incognito
The producer of Time to Live Again hired John 'JR' Robinson ( called "one of the most recorded drummers in history") who played drums on Michael Jackson tunes. I mention this solely to show we are mot messing around and think the song deserves the best.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Robinson_(drummer)
(Disclaimer: Apart from a nice voice, a golf glove, and the above, this is all I have in common with MJ. Ouch! Sorry MJ. You were a true natural)
So I am convinced I have the right sound this time. If you listen to the three finished demos above then you will see what I mean. Once they are mastered they will be ready for airplay.
CHALLENGES 
Main challenge is not having enough money to master then market music correctly. The music business is pretty much a closed shop, a monopoly, where only the signed artists get airplay. We used to get only  get 1% of the music out there played as it is run by the music industry. Spotify has evened the playing field so with good production and some marketing it is possible to get some traction if not signed.  However, you are still up against the machine - For example, at one pro studio, a huge band came in with an entourage of about 20 people, took one night to set up drums, did 8 takes the next day, done. Total cost about 5000 USD - for a single drum track. Another band spent 100 000 USD on album recordings and were just a mid-level band famous in their own country. Not made it internationally. If you are not signed it is like playing the PGA with a baseball bat. Not an excuse, but when you are up against top producers, massive budgets and marketing campaigns, inside contacts, it is hard to get to the sunlight. Even small things like instruments count -  a 5000 USD guitar is literally gonna sound than a 500 dollar one. All I have on par is what I can control - my voice and my lyrics - so gonna use them to the max, and which I why I put my heart and soul into my music.

This is my first time doing a Kickstarter but not my first pre-order campaign! It is an all-or-nothing deal. Of course, if any problems arise along the way, I will be in contact with all of you.

☆ Some packages from the manufacturer may include some defects causing a need for more orders. delaying shipping. I will be ordering extras in anticipation of this risk.

☆I am not responsible for any lost or stolen packages that may occur through the postal service or upon delivery.

☆No refunds will be given after the campaign has ended and pledges have been collected.

☆ Due to COVID-19 there may be shipping delays or issues with some international packages being accepted.

REWARDS
The final pins may vary slightly from the designs shown here.  Every single pin is handmade, there is expected to be minor defects or flaws. Standard grade pins will be used to fulfill pledges and these pins may have minor defects that are only visible under extremely close inspection. Pins with more noticeable flaws are lower grade and will NOT be used to fulfill pledges. Actual color or size of the pins may differ a little from the descriptions, but I'm confident that any differences will be minimal. I am working closely with a established manufacturer, to ensure smooth fulfillment of all the orders. 

TIMELINE
Delays in shipping and production of pins may occur when creating enamel pins. This may happen because of production errors and manufacturing defects. If there are any delays, all backers will be immediately updated! 

FULFILLMENT

Please double check your address to reduce the chance of a package being lost! Once a package is mailed, it is out of my control but I will do my best to assist and accommodate for any lost packages for TRACKED shipment. We always encourage you to upgrade by adding TRACKING to the shipping with a small fee for peace of mind.

ADDITIONAL FEES
Backers outside of the SG are responsible for any and all customs fees, import taxes, VAT, GST, or other additional costs associated with importing goods into their country and those costs are NOT included in their pledge or shipping cost.

REFUNDS & CANCELLATIONS
Once the campaign is complete, refunds or cancellations will not be issued for any reason. Please fully read over the campaign, and only pledge if you understand & accept the above estimated timeline and risks!

My name is Larry Williams, the CEO of Camel Gang. I was born and raised in Memphis, Tennessee. I grew up in a neighborhood of North Memphis known as New Chicago. It consistently ranks in the top 10 most dangerous neighborhoods in America. It is a poverty stricken neighborhood overrun with gang violence and drugs. One in eight people living there will commit a violent crime or go to prison. I attended Manassas High School and was a part of the high school football team, which gained notoriety in the Academy Award winning documentary “Undefeated”. I graduated from MHS in 2011. I had no real means to attend college, so I decided to join the military.
 
I joined the United States Army in 2011 at the age of 19. I was deployed on my first tour to Kuwait in 2013, leaving behind my girlfriend and newborn boy. On my first tour overseas with eight months passed and three months to go, I was feeling depressed and home sick. I missed my girlfriend and my son drastically. My son was only a few months old when I was deployed. The dry sand of Kuwait and the intense heat, over 130 degrees some days, began to wear on me. On the 10th day of July, 2013, my squadron leader gave us the word that we would be escorting a convoy of trucks through the Alseen Desert back to the Forward Operations Base.
 
While out on the mission, we came across a single shepherd who had been herding camels across the desert. Each camel carried a load of about 70 pounds on its back. The shepherd told us that they had gone several days without food or water. He then began to praise the camels. He explained that the beauty of a camel is its ability to endure what’s around it and to keep going. The camels never give up and “carry the load” no matter what conditions they encounter.
 
At that moment, I began to look at my life differently. I realized that giving up is not an option. That I had to “carry the load.” I had to keep going as the camel does. I realized I needed to continue the pursuit of my dreams by making the right decisions in my life. As soon as I got back to base, the camel was still on my mind. To help me remember, I had a camel logo embroidered on all of my personal belongings. I had my socks, caps, t-shirts, polos, and everything I had embroidered to keep me focused.
 
My whole unit decided they wanted the embroidered camel also. At that moment, we became the Camel Gang. I have since spread the word through the Camel Gang line that in life we all must “carry the load.” Most of all I am proud to offer The Camel Gang line of Apparel. 
We serve to honor the millions of men and women of the US Military and the millions of under privileged people who are out their trying hard everyday to "Carry The Load.

Over the past year making this film has taught us many lessons – we have listened, we have learnt lots and we have taken on board a lot of invaluable advice. 

Here are a few of the lessons:

FINISHING THE FILM – half the battle is done. Through the dedication and kindness of others we have half our footage in the can. Now we just need your help to get the rest in the bag, and then we can cross the finish line.

IMPACT – the domino effect of talking to people is that you find out just how many people are affected by conditions like epilepsy, whether personally or vicariously. Chelsea’s story impacts on us all and it will hopefully change the way we look at people who suffer from differing neurological conditions, or people who use medical cannabis. 

SPREADING THE WORD – with our new Kickstarter team behind us we can give people like Chelsea & Tamsin a voice. Not just to raise money but to get people talking. And when people start talking, people start helping.

We've already faced challenges, we've already faced risks and each one has been overcome thanks to the inspiration Chelsea's, and so many others alike, story instils in everyone involved. We promise never to give up until we get this film made and shared with all of you!!

Even once we’re funded, the main challenge we will be faced with is maintaining funding to keep this at a break-even cost. The daily news website is being funded on our own dime, which when coupled with a magazine with illustrators and contributors gets rather pricey. But we're doing this out of a love for the genre and gaming in general, which is why we've gone on for as long as we have without funding.

We may not get the subscription numbers to maintain this magazine over the long-term. As with all things on ARPGamer, we're doing this because we love the genre, gaming, and writing. Without adequate subscription levels, the diversity of our content may faulter and the magazine could potentially just become an ARPG guide book. Which, as fun as that still sounds, we'd prefer to keep with our current diversity of content.

Gamers may simply prefer the daily news website over the magazine. Simply put, it's cheaper and makes more sense to just visit our website to get your daily fix of ARPG news. To address this, we're trying to generate more unique and exclusive content to warrant the expenditure of a magazine. People obviously won't buy the magazine if it has no standalone value that the website doesn't already address. But we're pretty confident that the magazine will create value that complements the website without duplicating the same kind of content.

One final risk is that too many ARPGs are set to be released in 2013 and we'll get caught up playing them all. Let’s face it, a lot of good game titles are coming out soon and there are only so many hours in the day for us to choose between playing and writing.

Okay, fine, if you insist, we’ll keep writing when we could be playing.

We've truly grown over the past year and a half and are excited to expand Off Switch Magazine in 2013. While we still have a ton to learn about the process of creating, publishing, and distributing a quarterly magazine, we feel confident in our ability to make it happen. Trial and error are inevitable and so are mistakes, but by being honest and forthright with our backers we intend to keep lines of communication open and things running smoothly.

The Artist’s Challenge: When I asked a professional in the business directly about making an album, this is what I got: "Do one song at a time. Make this album like it's your first and your last, don't hold back. Have a deadline, but don’t rush the process of creativity.” It costs $2,000 to $10,000 to produce a song (the average budget is $200k from a major label). 
From an artist’s standpoint, I think that money does guarantee quality: the Challenge is getting the best performance from the most talented people, from their Hearts, not just showing up and thinking that it’s good enough when it can be better. Interpretations, what I hear and what others hear in their imaginations, they are not the same. This is a challenge that I hope will manifest itself above and beyond what we can imagine just as individuals. As an artist, a big challenge is finding that new sound without swaying to the industry’s demands of Their sound and images, of becoming something I’m not. Which means finding out who I am is a part of the journey.

The Challenge of Quality Distribution is no small feat. Nationwide physical distribution is the next step after creating the album.

The Risk: Not doing it. Not ever hearing these great songs fully produced in a professional manner. Not moving on to the next level as a professional. There’s always a risk when someone dares to change, to grow, to dream. This path for me is a huge risk in my life and my future. It’s all about the music, because creating music is a life style that's different than a working class hero’s. It’s always a risk in being different, and there's always a risk when you want to be real, when you want to just be you.






Budget

(Bare-bones minimum)

$2,000 per song    x 10 songs  =  $20,000
$2,500 mastering the songs
$2,500 initial CD distribution
$2,000 copyright, legal, IT- social network media
$2,000 videography
$1,000 promotions
$1,000 artwork & graphic designs
$4,000 fulfillment of pledge rewards + fees (Kickstarter, amazon, etc.)
________________________________________________________
TOTAL  :  $35,000

Touring Europe in 2015 is a very different equation! Times have changed significantly with the economic challenges most countries in the world are facing. This affects touring internationally with rising transportation costs as well as a variety of other expenses including the "backline" required for most USA bands to tour including the rental of instruments like acoustic bass and drums. Traveling by air makes it impossible to bring these aforementioned large instruments on the airplane. Another considerable challenge is housing particularly on off days. Now a days the bottom line is what comes in must match what goes out, and meeting this requirement can be VERY challenging indeed! Fortunately, there is a bedrock of support provided by my company "Cultural Odyssey" which at least guarantees a decent fee for the musicians in order to tour. If the expenses are greater than the income the musicians do not suffer! Cultural Odyssey takes the hit! This is an important policy that myself and my company, Cultural Odyssey, is and always will be commited to! Take care of the artists first and everything else will follow! Help us to meet the challenges stated above and it will be very much appreciated!

Funding! This is really my biggest problem when it comes to making the zine. I plan to release it in both physical and digital form both with a few differences between the two. As this is our first enamel pin project, we'd like to make sure the designs are manufacturable. We have already received the samples of the poison dart frog and the White's tree frog, and the other designs have been sent to the factory for quotations as well. 

To better represent the appearances of the frogs, we will use silkscreen printing to depict their colorations, so there will be no awkward metal outlines to hold in the enamel colors. However, there might be unwanted displacement in the silkscreens. We have ordered 10 samples of the White's tree frog to see if this will potentially be a significant issue in mass production, and we assure our backers we will ship out only the satisfactorily manufactured pins. In unlucky circumstances where the silkscreens in most sample pins are unsatisfactory, some details, specifically the highlights around the eyes and the mouths of the frogs, may be removed. 

The colors of the actual pins may differ slightly from the designs. Delays in manufacture are also possible. Though, as we have already begun the manufacture of the poison dart frog and the White's tree frog, we have built a trusted relationship with the manufacturer. We are confident in resolving any issues that might come up.

Lastly, there might be delays in shipping due to the COVID-19 pandemic. We will notify our backers once their packages have been shipped out.

In addition, we will not have the financial ability to apply to film festivals. The biggest risk is that A Different Script will not have the opportunity to be shared with audiences around the world!

We already have the venue booked, and the bands are being approached. The gig is going to happen! But, how well it can happen depends on the funding we receive from you fine people. There are always risks with a live event and we’ll do our best to minimize them; a band may not turn up, some equipment might go down, the fire sprinklers might go off… but we can cope with adversity. Without your funding we’ll have to borrow a PA (might be dubious quality or a compromise on what we need), we won’t have any event lighting (other than what we can bring in for the cameras) and we’ll be have to cover it on a couple of borrowed cameras (not to our usual standard). Also we're not sure we can do it as a webcast with your help… 

It’ll be OK, and we’ll have our gig, but will it be amazing? No-one wants a damp squib! Our main challenge isn't delivering the event, but delivering one that will help to spread the message of community in music which we believe in so strongly. And you can be part of that!

There is always a big risk in opening a business in the foodservice industry, but pizza has higher profit margins than most concepts, and I'm confident our pizza speaks for itself. We are located in a walkable neighborhood with the ability to have a wide delivery radius.

We already have a date set to open and, barring any major setbacks, we are expecting a very successful opening weekend.

The main risk that could potentially disrupt our scheduled opening is the weather! No one wants soggy fries, and we don't want you to have to party with us in the rain. Our contingency plan is to simply push things back a week and try again! 

Another consideration is location; we are currently working on securing permissions for several spots that the truck can rotate through! 

'And finally - supply chain issues. Due to the current state of ingredient, paper goods, etc. availability, getting everything we want may not be possible, but proper substitutions will make things run just as well!

As all new businesses do, I’m sure I will run into obstacles along the way.  By funding this project quickly, I’m hoping to stay ahead of potential supply chain issues by placing equipment orders sooner rather than later.  I am working closely with the local health department, licensors, and veteran food truck owners, so any unforeseen hurdles and red tape are approached with solid knowledge and realistic expectations.  I also have a wide variety of local, expert help for the renovation - but as with any project, there may be unforeseen hiccups.  I am determined to launch Jenny Marie’s this coming spring and will work through complications as they arise.  I’m looking forward to rising to and growing from the challenges.

Color variation - As no two computer screens display colors exactly the same, what appear on your computer screen may not be exactly the same for the actual product. However, I will work closely with my manufacturer to make sure all the colors appear as close as possible to my design intent. 

Minor design adjustments - All the designs shown here are conceptual designs. During production, some minor changes might be required to ensure the product is manufacturable. Usually these changes are very minimal, and will not have an impact on the overall aesthetics or the turnaround time. However, if any issues arise, I will send out an update to all my backers immediately.

Defects - If any of the products (pins, stickers, and postcards) are defective upon receipt from my manufacturer, I will get them remade. This means the order for my backer will be delayed. I will send out an update immediately if that happens.

Logistically an island is always a challenge.  Especially when said island is a UNESCO world heritage site accessed only by ferry and free of motor vehicles for equipment transport. This is where we plan to install a full-scale concert stage, astronomical observatory, and video projection screens.  It will be challenging and require robust support, however we are not the first to organize on Gorée and are reassured by the fact that past concert events have been successful.  We are working to coordinate as best as possible with the Port Authority / Ferry embarcadère on issues surrounding the transport of equipment and people to and from the festival location.  Asamaan will benefit greatly from its social connection to the resident community on Gorée island and will be able to mobilize significant volunteer support.

As with any project, the completion of this documentary isn't without risks.  In Guatemala, there are concerns about safety and security. Travel using public transportation is complicated in the rural areas and insecure throughout the country. In locations where competition for resources and  opposition to outsiders is strong, we risk attracting negative attention by arriving with a camera and crew.  To mitigate these risks, we will travel using private transportation, always accompanied by community members, local officials, and/or security.

Another risk to the completion of the problem is that the community members either aren't interested in talking about the subject, don't see the trash as a problem, or are fearful about expressing themselves on camera.  These issues are always a risk when filming a documentary but we believe we are well-placed to overcome them since we will be working through people of confidence to the communities and will never arrive alone or without precedent.

Finally, the biggest risk we face, has nothing to do with the production of the documentary but about it's reception. Upon screening the documentary, we risk negative attention from companies producing single-use products and from the government who has yet to assign financial resources to the problem. However, this big risk is worth it if the film has the desired outcome described above.

The Post Office trial is due to begin on 5 November 2018. Even if this kickstarter reaches its target, I will make a loss. I am just about capable of swallowing that loss through my savings and/or by taking on professional commissions around this story. I am hoping to get over-funded.

If I can't raise the target funding every penny pledged returns to my backers. As a result I will not cover every day of the trial and will need to fill my diary with non-Post Office related work. That's why I'm running the kickstarter to 15 October rather than the start of the trial. If I fail to raise £3000 before 15 October I've still got a couple of weeks to find alternative paid work in November.

If, thanks to your generosity, this kickstarter reaches its £3000 target, the risks as I see them are this:

1) The trial does not happen. 

This could be because the Post Office might settle before the trial starts or the subpostmasters could withdraw their claim. If either happens before the fundraising period ends, you will not be required to honour your pledges.

If the trial collapses or the claim is settled between the end of the fundraising period and start of the trial, I will refund any honoured pledges in full and cancel the requirement to pay all un-honoured pledges. I will swallow any fees imposed by kickstarter to ensure everyone gets what they donated.

2) The trial is postponed. 

If the trial is postponed, I will attend the trial during the rescheduled dates and report it accordingly. I currently have nothing in my diary which can't be moved to accommodate this.

3) The trial starts, then collapses or is settled. 

Even if the trial collapses or is settled in its first week there should be enough evidence (both written and spoken) put into the public domain to write daily blog posts throughout November. I'll also investigate the aftermath, speaking to the key players and widening the journalistic reach of the project by interviewing participants, legal observers, interested parties, MPs and other influential figures in the story. You will get your money's worth. In this way all backers at every level will have their rewards fulfilled.

4) I fall ill or suffer a family emergency and am unable to fulfil my commitment, partially or wholly, in person. 

If I am required, through illness or any other unforseen circumstance, to absent myself from court for one day or more, I will arrange for a trained journalist to attend court on my behalf and compile a court report in my absence. I will then ensure that court report is published on www.postofficetrial.com. If I fall ill before the trial starts I will arrange for a trained journalist to attend the trial on my behalf. If I fall so ill I am unable to communicate or I die, I have arranged that you will get your money back. No one can predict the future, but if it helps, I haven't missed a day's work for several years.

5) Legal restrictions stop the reporting of the trial. 

It is conceivable that the judge may order some elements of the trial not be reported. This is extremely unlikely. It is almost impossible to imagine a situation whereby the proceedings of the whole trial would be deemed unreportable. If this happens it would arguably be a bigger story than the trial itself, and I will honour the rewards in the same way proposed in point 3) above - covering the story as fully as possible.

As a student film, we are working within a relatively modest budget to bring our artistic vision to fruition. Adventures & Outings is a program that is close to the hearts of our crew members. We would like to be able to tell the story of Lori Gray and the group to the best of our ability and with the help of our backers (you!) we believe we can.

There are risks in any filmmaking project; losing footage, commuting long distances, equipment failure, and technical difficulties are only a few. However, the Adventures & Outings crew has extensive previous filmmaking experience, and we are confident that we have taken appropriate safety measures and have the knowledge to successfully make this documentary as professional and efficient as possible.

The truth is there are any number of fluke things that could come up and complicate this project. There could be be hurdles in getting the piece booked at venues in the US and abroad. As with any project, there could be some unforeseen legal complications. I am a determined and tenacious person though. I have been making films for almost 20 years, and I've also made several other live documentaries before, so I am confident that I could overcome any reasonable challenges that might arise.

The biggest risk would not be getting funded to the basic 20-30 minute film. Kickstarter is an 'all or nothing' crowdfunding platform where if I don't raise my goal, then I won't get the funds. In the worst case scenario that I'm not able to raise the funding goal, I would still try and produce a 5-10 minute film to get something out to the public.

That being said, I do believe that we'll will meet our goal, and beyond. If our stretch goals are met, then there will be risks of traveling internationally to the third world with expensive camera gear and hard drives. 

Additionally, biggest challenge will be to compile all the footage into a compelling narrative. However, I believe that the filmmaking team and the stories are more than up to the challenge, and trust in faith that the project will be a success.

Keeping the project going on once we are done with the first edition is our major challenge. 

Furthermore, reaching other international locations, getting in contact with freelancers and finding external financing suppose other important obstacles.

The limited time we have to ask for your help means that we are still looking at a few cart options. There is a slight chance that none of the three owners will sell their cart to us, although we believe that to be unlikely. In this case, we do have an option of renting a cart for the The First Annual Champaign Craft Beer Festival. Backers who have chosen hotdog party packages will have an option of another type of catered event (bbq, ramen, etc.)

Also, we are still negotiating a contract with the The First Annual Champaign Craft Beer Festival and in the process of completing our proposal to the Champaign Urbana Public Health Department. The chances of us not attending the fest are possible, but once again we believe unlikely. In this case, we will still purchase the hotdog cart and the rewards to our party package supporters will be satisfied; however, the half-off ticket holders will be given a voucher for any future event.

Defending such a groundbreaking visual experience (that dates back from a 1956 film so you can see how new and innovative we are trying to be) wasn't a piece of cake. Nowadays most interviews are what we call "talking heads" (someone talks to you sitting on a chair and archival footage comes to illustrate his or her points) and that didn't seem very entertaining to us. But because we chose a more original take on things we hit a few setbacks trying to locate international vendors and distributors who couldn't really envisioned what we had in mind (i.e. a technique that has been around for at least 60 years). That means even if we can finish the film by December, we might not be able to release it just yet. Though we will try our best to get it to you before anyone else.

The other challenges are obviously related to filmmaking. Exterior locations need permits, good weather, and are subject to a long list of hazardous problems that could ensue from equipment fails to misplaced crew. Though this crew has more than 500 filming experience combined (200 from the director alone) so we know our stuff. We know how to prepare and how to get back with the images we have in mind. And that's exactly what we'll do if you support us.

We’ve both been in the restaurant business since we were teenagers, so we are intimately familiar with the risks inherent in this industry. Challenges to the success of our project include truck performance issues, weather conditions, location limitations, customer preference, and customer awareness. 

Truck Performance-
Without the truck we can’t serve food, so keeping the truck up and running remains paramount to our operation. Our truck will undergo regular preventative maintenance to maintain consistent performance - no surprises. We hope to invest in a truck that can run on biodiesel in warm weather to reduce emissions and expenses.

Weather-
Weather effects all food trucks. We love barbecue because it is truly a year-round cuisine - just as good on hot summer days as on a blustery winter night. Working with tap and cocktail rooms ensures year-round customers, and we plan on sending Toph inside to get orders and deliver food right to the table so our customers can stay warm and dry (just another step in top-notch customer service that sets us apart!). 

Location limitations-
The food truck industry is still relatively new to the Twin Cities, and it is possible that public opinion could sway and lead to more strict zoning, which would impact our ability to operate consistently. This is why we will focus on partnering with businesses, taprooms and cocktail rooms with private parking lots for the majority of operating days to avoid the race for the few street spots in Downtown Minneapolis (and the associated risk of tickets, fines and lost business). We will become members of the MN Food Truck Association and join other food truck operators in advocating for zoning and legal statutes that support mobile food vendors in Minneapolis and the greater Twin Cities area.

Customer preference and awareness-
With so many options for food trucks, how will Bark and the Bite stand out? We know no one else is doing the kind of craft barbecue that we bring to the table - our processes, experience and passion set us apart. Our menu features vegetarian and gluten-free options to make barbecue accessible to as many people as possible. We will use social media extensively to share specials, promote our menu and share our location. Partnering with local breweries and distilleries will allow us to build regulars, create unique and one-of-a-kind pairings and operate year round. We will also be available for catering and special events.

Fortunately, with the truck being already secured and in use as a food truck, there is little work to be done. The Health Department loves the truck. Although there are a ton of great events and markets in NWI, it may be a challenge finding outlets for the truck. The truck is a little older, but it's in great shape. If, in the unfortunate event that we lose the truck (accident, malfunction, etc), we hope that we will have in that time built up enough of a following to either acquire a new truck or fix the existing truck.

The only risk we foresee is the chance of shipping a little bit later than the estimated dates, due to the project being extremely over-funded. It’s not a bad risk to have! So we’ve factored in extra time to account for this, as large-scale productions involve considerably more planning.

We’ll provide you with regular project updates, so should any production or shipping delays occur, we can let you know about it ASAP.

Please note that the flashlight shown in images and video on this page is our functional prototype, and we reserve the right to make minor design alterations to all elements as needed. The dimensions may need to be adjusted during mass production to ensure we produce the best flashlight we can, for everyone.

This isn't our first rodeo. Our team has been in the apparel business since 2013 and with our production partners, we have decades of experience bringing high-quality outdoor clothing to market. Our factory partner is ready to go, with capacity booked on their line waiting for our order to start production. We've gone through a full sampling and testing process with these pieces to ensure the final product will be to our exact spec.

While we've done this before, and we've done our best to prepare, there can still be delays in production from things like fabric getting held up in customs and delays at the factory. At his previous company, our founder created the customer service processes and he prides himself on being transparent and helpful to supporters. We will be straightforward with any delays and do our best to be communicative and supportive through the process.

With your support, we can make this happen and continue a brand focused on creating high-quality clothing for people who want to own less!

Cheers,

The LIVSN team

The main hurdle we have to overcome is getting funding by our deadline. So it's up to you! 
We want to get you more bang for your buck! Then you can see these boards at your local skate shop!

I made a commitment to myself, my family, and friends who have also sacrificed along this journey, my past clients, and those I will have the honor to support in the future, to finish this book. Of course, funding is tight and there's a lot involved with making this possible, but I am committed to making this work accessible and inspiring.

The main risk is not getting it published, but a successful kickstarter should help. Not finding 100 people willing to participate is a potential risk, but unlikely. Not getting enough funding could mean the book is just the hopes and dreams of 100 people local to me, which won't be as good as if there were more international participants. Other than that, the other risk is ensuring all backers receive their rewards and are happy!

All the illustrations are complete, I have a reliable printer in place and have already received a sample deck. All card images are of the sample deck. So excluding any totally unforeseen issues, there should be no problems with production. 
The only potential issue will be with the shipping and the global corona situation. Decks are only due to ship in June/July, so we should hopefully be through the worst of it by then. The worst case scenario I can envision is that shipping is delayed a month or so because of the postal service having issues with the virus. That said, all international backers will have their decks sent tracked and local UK decks will be Signed For delivery. So again, I can't see there being a problem.

Please be aware, as screens vary, deck colours may differ from how you see it in the photos on your device.

As with my last successful Kickstarter project, I will provide all backers with a monthly update that includes progress and highlights, as well as any challenges or anticipated setbacks.

The two most difficult areas of this project are the nature of participatory storytelling and technology development.

I believe that if this Kickstarter is successfully funded, we will have a critical mass of wine enthusiasts, content creators and wine producers to tell a comprehensive story of a year in American wine.

My biggest concern in this area is not having coverage of all American wine regions, which I will attempt to overcome by working diligently with established wine associations for American wine regions and making the cost to participate fair and affordable for everyone.

There are always risks when working with technology: multiple devices, operating systems or other unknowns that are constantly changing. These risks will be mitigated by using widely adopted technologies (i.e. HTML5) and established standards for accessibility (i.e. W3C validation.) 

By using existing platforms like Instagram, Wordpress, Vimeo and Twitter to submit content, we'll be reducing our technology cost burden while ensuring accessibility and ease of use for anyone, anywhere.

History and Myth

Professor Buzzkill’s greatest challenge is to show people how myths and misunderstandings about history are not just inaccurate. Myths can serve a useful purpose by providing an intriguing and entertaining way to examine the bigger issues in history connected to them. We can overcome this challenge by relying on our extensive research training in history, our vast network of fellow historians willing to help, and our charismatic style and approach to history and new media.

Technology

The second challenge is technical. We need professional help promoting the blog and getting it in front of the eyes of the right people in the media world. We also need help with the sound engineering of the podcast. We have plenty of media experience, but it’s been on the speaking side of the microphone, not the production side. To overcome this challenge, we have already lined up some of the best podcast engineers and promoters around. This will make sure our podcast sounds great and gets out to as many people as possible.

Similar to other websites, our website faces security related issues that impacts user experience. As the website’s visibility has increased, hackers have made the platform a target for numerous and continued attacks and our goal initially is to hire out a security firm to increase security on the website.

A secondary risk is being drowned out by other organizations with larger budgets, which will impact our contributors who seek a broad audience for their work. The challenge is marketing and reaching as a wide an audience as possible on a shoestring budget. We have made great strides with the resources available; however, in order to push International Policy Digest to the next level more funding will be necessary in order to promote our contributors.

Rewards

In donating the International Policy Digest, you will be supporting an innovative, online news organization that seeks to educate and inform those interested in exploring new ideas. Your gift will help maintain a slowly disappearing concept: true independent news. As politics and conglomerates have come to shape the current media landscape, rest assured that those at International Policy Digest will never devolve its content to click-bait infotainment or replace practical analyses with ideological confrontations.

The biggest challenges I see are the unexpected day to day problems.  Truck problems.  Issues with the city.  People not showing up for work.  I hope to minimize these risks by keeping the truck well maintained, keeping in communication with the city and hiring great people.

Although this is our first ambitious project, our team members have the experience to successfully complete the project.  Most of the content is already ready for publication. The main risk of the project remains the global shipping and paper prices, however, our goal already foresees this to some extent in the original goal. We are also prepared to solve any problems on an ad hoc and personal basis.

After walking around the Salton Sea, training missions, years of interviewing, filming and events, many film challenges (hard drive and drone crashes, wet & salty equipment, bug bites, blisters & heat exhaustion)... are luckily behind us. Throughout this process, the local residents have been so kind, helpful and determined to help us achieve our work by reducing many of those that came our way.

Looking forward, we face significant risks regarding the Sea-to-Sea walk from the Sea of Cortez to the Salton Sea, following a path through Mexico and the Laguna Salada. This is a very remote area, and any accident this far from civilization could be serious.

In addition, starting January 1st of 2018, significant amounts of fresh water will be transferred to the Pacific coast - expediting the impending ecological, health, and economic disaster. 

The challenge will be to get this film and the word out to as many people as possible, especially governing bodies and leaders throughout the southwest in order to pave the way for a sustainable future. We simply cannot continue to stand idly by as time has literally run out.
